story:
WHO: Planet Namaste - We are a group of yoga instructors and school educators who envision supporting and educating our communities and schools on the wellness factor of yoga.

WHAT: Onsite Yoga instruction for local schools. Curriculum is aligned with National PE and health standards, in addition to be an approved Social Emotional curriculum by CASEL. ﻿

  • $400 provides one month(4 sessions) of Bring Your Teacher to Lunch Yoga. 
  • $500 provides one month (4 sessions) of yoga specifically for teachers at their site. 
  • $1000 provides 3 months(12 sessions) of an onsite YogaClub designed to be held before or after school and includes students, teachers, staff, and parents. This program is suggested as an alternative to detention. 
  • $2000 provides an 8 hour professional development workshop for up to 6 school teachers on how to incorporate yoga (and chair yoga) into their daily curriculum. 

There are 17 schools in the Burbank Unified School District. We hope to raise enough money to provide one of our programs to each site.

WHY: The statistics are sobering. Half of all serious adult psychiatric illnesses – including major depression, anxiety disorders, and substance abuse – start by 14 years of age. Three-fourths of them are present by 25 years of age. (ActiveMinds.org) Anorexia is the leading cause of death among women ages 14-24. (NEDA) Schools are seeing an unprecedented number of students struggling with stress and depression. Colleges are reporting that students are not prepared to handle the challenges of college. Yoga can help!


WHERE: Burbank, CA and other schools within 10 mile radius of 91505


WHEN: Commencing Fall 2017 - the new school year!

This campaign is specifically to bring yoga to school sites; however, our company has a much larger vision of educating our community on yoga and wellness. Please read over the other areas we are working to get a better sense of who we are and what we want to do. 


Yoga is 5,000 year old Eastern discipline that integrates the mind, body, and inner resource. Yoga is becoming more mainstream in the West and starting to be honored for its wisdom in healing and nurturing the whole person.

Planet Namaste’s vision is to create a space that is inclusive of all body types and all ability levels. Our hope is to provide classes that will contribute to the healing and nurturing of every individual. We want to provide support to those who are in various stages of healing and recovery, in addition to those who are at differing levels of physical abilities.

Our business structure has three main components: community, education, and advocacy. Planet Namaste honors the tradition of yoga being a community focused practice. It’s not just what we learn on the mat, it’s also what we take from the mat and spread to the community. With this mind, Planet Namaste is involved in extensive community outreach. Our main target is our local neighborhoods. Other community targets include chiropractors, schools, physical therapists, our local hospital, and various rehab and recovery centers, including eating disorder programs. Planet Namaste also reaches out to other yoga centers, schools, and health centers. We are currently creating a community Health and Wellness Alliance, made up of local business owners that work directly in the wellness industry, where we combine our strengths to provide education to our neighbors, hold Wellness Workshops, and be a source of support.

Another component is education. We currently provide classes for kids from pre-k to 12th grade. The classes focus on the physical and emotional development of the various age groups with the intention of increasing focus, self-awareness, self-control, self-esteem, and body positive thinking. The non-competitive environment encourages students to start where they are, no matter where that is. Additionally, we are working on  a comprehensive, cross-disciplinary curriculum that meets National standards in health, PE, and social emotional learning. This curriculum would also incorporate life skills including empathy, resiliency, and empowerment. 

Lastly, our third component is mental health advocacy. We would like to raise awareness and acceptance about mental wellness and how yoga can support those that struggle with anxiety, stress, eating disorders, and other disabilities.

story:
Envision a world with a small gap between urban and rural communities...

This means quality education, less brain-drain or emigration of talented individuals who could play an active role in their community development, and more productivity and heritage preservation. This is what inspires us to champion the Educate Future Authors project in Zambia.

I am Nelson David Bassey, a third year BEng (Hons) Mechanical Engineering student at INTI International University in Malaysia, part of the Laureate network. I am also a managing director (Asia) of the Stella Project Ltd, a Zambian registered not-for-profit company.  Educate Future Authors is one of our stellar projects.

We believe that one of the best ways to narrow this rural-urban gap is by creating access to quality education. And quality education begins with access to quality educational resources and infrastructures – much of what is lacking in many rural communities in Zambia today. Our mission is to identify such communities and work towards providing the resources they need to provide quality education to children and youth.

United Nations statistics show that over 58 million children in the world do not have access to education, with a majority in sub-Saharan Africa. We want to be a part of the movement to close that gap as quickly as possible.


Your Contributions Will Help Us Complete Phase 1

Your contributions will help us complete Phase 1 (Identify & Measure) of the three project phases below, and establish the relationships needed to begin Phase 2 and Phase 3.

What We Need

  • Should the entire goal not be reached, the funds given will be distributed accordingly and travel dates adjusted according to the funds available. 
  • Should the goal be exceeded, every other donated fund will be channeled to the first center which we will be equipping.
  • Should the actual trip expense fall short of the amount donated, the remaining funds will be channeled toward the first center which we will be equipping (Kalulushi Municipal Council Library).


The Impact

The Stella Projects are creating access to quality education and resources, equipping youth to play an active role in the socio-economic development of their communities, and reducing crime rates and preventable diseases through knowledge empowerment.

A key aspect of our business model and approach is to:

  1. Garner support for local businesses and organizations
  2. Create opportunities for youths to make a difference in their communities
  3. Create space for other innovative projects to take place in communities.
  4. Reduce the migration of talent from the community for better education opportunities.
  5. Cultivate local talent, ideas and intelligence.


Risks & Challenges

One of the risks we face is not being as fruitful in terms of meeting with prospective partners, as a result of visiting in December, a festive period of the year, and being there for only 7 days. The visiting season poses another challenge as movement may be limited due to rain and mud slides which may result in inefficiency.

To solve these challenges, we will reach out to prospective partners one month in advance to set up appointments on the dates we will be there. Also, being an African who grew up in Nigeria, I have lived in similar weather conditions, so adapting might not be much of a trouble. However, resorting to use a rented car minimizes the risk of inefficiency.


Other Ways You Can Help Includes:

  1. Make a pledge.
  2. Share our campaign with your closest five (5) contacts, friends and family who can support our cause.
  3. Share about our campaign on social media to help us reach or goals as quickly as possible.
Thank you for taking action with us to Educate Future Authors!

story:
Our Bernie Sticker For Students GrassRoots Effort
It's pretty simple folks,  we see a dire need for Bernie 2016 Bumper Stickers on College campuses across the United States.  A YUGE need.   
As you may or may not know, College Students are not always rolling in the cash, therefore buying stickers, or campaign supplies in bulk is usually not an option for them.  This is why we want to help them!!
We are huge Bernie supporters and are active in a grassroots campaign in Asheville, North Carolina and the surrounding area.  After a an event called Bernie Bash we put on here, we had a few thousand stickers left over after using the funds we raised at the event.  We wanted these stickers to go to the people who needed them most.  

Then we started to think big, as Bernie often suggests.  We understand that with the right vision and the help from fellow supporters, that this grassroots efforts can be funded by the PEOPLE, by Bernie supporters, and that we can get tens of thousands of stickers or more to campuses across the country.  Our Goal is 100,000 STICKERS!!
College Students are our FUTURE!!  Their collective voice holds more weight than many realize!  Our goal is to further empower them to let it be known, that we the people, are for Bernie Sanders as our next President!  We are tired of politics as usual, and we are indeed ready for a Political Revolution!!

   

The Impact You'll be Making

You know that feeling you get when you're driving down the road and you see someone with a Bernie Sanders sticker on their vehicle??  It might be curiousity if you don't know about Bernie.  It might be joy that someone else is supporting Bernie, because you feel so strongly about his message and what he can do for this country and this world.   It might be reassurance, that someone else is feeling the Bern and his call for a Political Revolution.  Maybe you thought you were alone.  Well we want a lot more people, especially on college campuses to get those same feelings.   We want to create a buzz around every campus in the United States.  

If you get the majority of College Students in the United States on board with Bernie, we WIN the election.  Period.
Every $5.00 you give will help us get 25 stickers to students across the country!! That's like a beer at your local pub or a mocha latte at the Starbucks down the street.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Please visit our Facebook page!!  
https://www.facebook.com/groups/767387390055455/
Join our Group, and join the discussion.  Talk to College Students who are receiving our stickers!  Listen to their stories!  Ask questions!!

We do what we can in life.  This is our way of trying to make a difference.  We hope that you'll consider supporting what we are trying to do.  It's not just about Bernie, it's about all of us and the future of our country and our planet.  It's about time for a real Political Revolution!!  A government for the People, by the People.  

BERNIE 2016  - FEEL THE BERN!!

story:
SafetyCurtain Details:

The main ingredient in the SafetyCurtain is Kevlar -- a polymer with remarkable tensile strength and the ability to resist penetration -- the same material used in bulletproof vests. But, while vests and the SafetyCurtain serve the same purpose -- to protect the people behind them from penetrating bullets -- they perform their functions differently and have different Kevlar requirements. In particular, a protective vest incorporates many layers of Kevlar -- around 30 -- but the SafetyCurtain will require far fewer. A vest has to dissipate a bullet's impact in a very short distance, before it has a chance to damage the fragile human who's pressed rigidly against it. It must take account of what's called "backface signature" and spread out the force of the transmitted energy impact over its relatively small area, to prevent blunt force trauma. The SafetyCurtain will provide a large area for this dissipation of force ...and no one will be leaning against it -- so, far fewer layers of Kevlar will be required. Nevertheless, the SafetyCurtain will meet the same Type IIIA standards as the National Institute of Justice has established for bulletproof vests.

The energy absorbing feature of the SafetyCurtain will be enhanced by specially designed attachments for connecting the curtain to the floor and ceiling tracks. These will incorporate short, heavy-duty springs -- helping to absorb the force of bullets and thwarting a shooter's efforts to kick the SafetyCurtain open. The durable floor track will be very low profile ... and will come with a laser-guided system for positioning the ceiling track exactly correctly.

When installed, while not deployed the SafetyCurtain will retract into a protected enclosure. This will protect the Kevlar from UV exposure and excessive moisture levels ... and, because the case can be painted or decorated in any way desired, it will make the installation less intrusive. To further protect the Kevlar, the outer layers of the SafetyCurtain will be printed material. When deployed, the shooter side -- i.e., the side he'd encounter when entering a protected classroom -- will display some "disturbing" sort of optical design -- the sort of thing it hurts your eyes to look at. On the protected side, a variety of soothing images and colors are possible.

In a classroom protected with a SafetyCurtain, a shooter would see this:

Instead of this:

 

Timeline and Budget:

Paul has already made a good contact with a polymer expert at the University of New Hampshire. This prof has confirmed the soundness of the idea -- i.e., that the SafetyCurtain will work! He's suggested that a newer polymer might work even better than Kevlar, has offered to put Paul in touch with a mechanical engineer (to help design the springy attachments) and will serve as a materials science consultant once the project gets going. Paul's also made contact with a local policeman -- who gave him an old vest to take apart and has offered to use the police shooting range to do informal tests of early prototypes.

This IndieGoGo campaign is meant to fund Research & Development to capitalize on the ideas and planning done so far. The steps to be taken are pretty clear ... but we have no way of knowing how much some of these steps will cost. Converting the provisional patent to a full, regular patent will cost $10-15K (according to the Internet). Materials for experiments? Consulting fees? Prototyping? Lab testing and NIJ certification of the final product? Setting up for initial production? Neither of us has experience with this sort of thing -- not even enough to make truly sensible estimates of the expenses entailed. However, the campaign goal -- if we reach it -- should be enough to fund us all the way through R&D and into some kind of limited production! Please consider making a contribution!!

By the way -- although it's really quite premature -- we plan to go into production in Arkansas. That's where Lynnie lives ... and she'll be in charge of this phase of things -- finding a building for the factory, buying equipment, hiring and supervising workers. Lynnie's plan is to hire workers who have been in rehab -- who often have trouble finding jobs and are thrown back into the same conditions which caused their problems in the first place. By paying a good wage and treating them fairly, we can help them have a good chance to turn their lives around -- while manufacturing a product entirely within the USA!

* * * * * * * *

FAQs

What will the SafetyCurtain look like when it's not in use?

When retracted, the SafetyCurtain will reside in a box-like housing ... bolted to a wall of the classroom. The curtain itself will be completely out of sight. At present, the plan is to make this floor-to-ceiling housing in plain white. If it's painted in the color of the classroom walls, it will just look like the wall is jutting out there. Otherwise, it could be decorated in any way desired ...or serve as a bulletin board ... or etc..

OK. So it will be bolted to one wall and locked to another. But, why can't a shooter just kick it in? What makes it secure on all 4 sides?

The curtain is attached to the mechanism of the accordion door. This mechanism is then attached to the tracks on which it will glide. For the SafetyCurtain, these attachments will incorporate heavy-duty springs ... which will absorb the impact of a kick. Moreover, the high tensile strength of the Kevlar will resist a steel-toed boot as well as it does a bullet.


What will it cost? Won't it be too expensive for schools to buy?

The honest answer is: We really don't know what it will cost. Certain R&D tasks need to be accomplished before a good estimate might be given. Preliminary investigations into material costs have led us to believe that the SafetyCurtain can be produced and sold at a non-outrageous price! Both of us value frugality and efficiency and we both recognize how strained school budgets already are -- so we're aiming to offer the finished product at the lowest price possible.


Will it work?

Yes, it will! When Paul began to take his own idea seriously, one of the first things he did was to reach out to a polymer expert in the Materials Science department at University of New Hampshire -- to find out if the idea was feasible -- if it could work. The response was unequivocally positive! He made several helpful suggestions ... and is willing to act as a consultant once the project gets going. Moreover, once the SafetyCurtain is prototyped, it will go to one of the official labs that grant NIJ certifications ... and will have to meet the same standards as do bulletproof vests.


What sizes will it come in?

As we currently plan it: Any size you need. We'll probably offer stock lengths ... where the next length up will always work. Probably a few stock heights -- where the next height down will work (via flexible attachments to the ceiling, shielded by a protective apron). Unless a classroom is really enormous or has a cathedral ceiling, we'll be making a SafetyCurtain which will fit!


Is there any reason why these are restricted to classroom use? What if I want one for my office space at work?

Teachers and kids cowering in classrooms were what spurred the idea of the SafetyCurtain -- the need to give our kids the security they should have at school. But, there's no reason why they couldn't be installed in other places. Flexible track even opens the possibility of enclosing individual cubicles.


How far away do the kids have to be from the curtain so they don't get hurt?

It will only be necessary that no one be leaning directly against the SafetyCurtain. Otherwise, students and teachers can move freely within the protected area of the room.


Will the lock hold ... or can it be shot off?

The lock will be on the protected side of the SafetyCurtain, so it can't be shot off. It will be something simple -- like a padlock which hangs on the wall near the hasp which will get locked to the deployed curtain.


Will the SafetyCurtain protect all the kids in a school?

Sadly, no. They'll only protect the kids in the rooms which have them. Moreover, people in the room where a shooter starts a rampage might not have much opportunity to get behind the barrier, even if they have one. The benefits of the SafetyCurtain are for those who aren't in the opening line of fire.

* * * * * * * *

Who we are:

Lynnie Bat-Abba:  I'm a Nurse and a Professor of English, but my heart is with my children and grandchildren. My sister and I are raising her two small grandsons – having moved to a farm in the mountains of Arkansas, where we hope to keep them safe. Eight of my nine grandchildren are being home-schooled, keeping them out of reach to those selfish lunatics who shoot little kids. But, this option isn't open to everyone.

My nursing experience of over 20 years has put me in direct contact with all ages, but my primary interest has been Hospice and the care of very small children with severe disabilities. Many of these children are enrolled in special education within public schools. They are the most defenseless of all in a shooting situation.

I was excited by the idea of the SafetyCurtain because I know the pain of losing a child. At least I know my daughter died quietly, not screaming in fear and pain. No parent should have to suffer the unending loss of a child – but, when they are murdered,  there is no peace or restitution which can erase the anguish. Implementing a way to protect our little ones is a way of doing our best to care for them. Sending our children to school shouldn't cause us to panic. We must be proactive. The SafetyCurtain would, at very least, alleviate some fear ... and at best, bring our babies home to us safe and sound -- not to bury, but to hold and cherish!

 

Paul Fischler: By education, I'm a philosopher. In the long-ago, I taught the subject at Cornell and a few other places. By nature, though, I'm an entrepreneur and "inventor" -- trying to think up simple solutions to some of the problems of ordinary life. Sadly, school shootings have become one such "ordinary" problem -- and the news reports I heard prompted the idea for the SafetyCurtain.

I'll be in charge of all the Research & Development ... and have already acquired more knowledge of guns and ballistic materials than I ever expected to need! I'll be working with a polymer expert (to determine the best material for the SafetyCurtain and the best way of using it) and a mechanical engineer (to design the springy attachments which will keep the SafetyCurtain secure) -- both faculty members at UNH.

My aim here is to create a product -- at the lowest cost possible -- which will protect our kids from flying bullets ... and from the trauma of hiding under desks or in closets while some homicidal maniac attacks their building. I can't think of how to stop the loonies from launching such attacks -- but keeping kids safe seems doable!

* * * * * * * *

If you can contribute, that's wonderful! But, that's not the only way you can help get this project off the ground. You can -- if you would be so kind -- spread the word as widely as possible in tweets, blogs, forums, emails and your social networks ... and by using the IndieGoGo share tools -- helping us make some noise about this useful product. We all want our kids to feel safe in school. You can be instrumental in bringing that about! Please do what you can. Thank you!!

* * * * * * * *

For those who contribute $25, we will thank you with your own Genuine Certificate of Goodness ... with your name in place of Jennifer's, of course. Properly framed, it would occupy the same space and carry the same weight as almost any diploma! Please contribute!

When installed, while not deployed the SafetyCurtain will retract into a protected enclosure. This will protect the Kevlar from UV exposure and excessive moisture levels ... and, because the case can be painted or decorated in any way desired, it will make the installation less intrusive. To further protect the Kevlar, the outer layers of the SafetyCurtain will be printed material. When deployed, the shooter side -- i.e., the side he'd encounter when entering a protected classroom -- will display some "disturbing" sort of optical design -- the sort of thing it hurts your eyes to look at. On the protected side, a variety of soothing images and colors are possible.
In a classroom protected with a SafetyCurtain, a shooter would see this:

Instead of this:

 

Timeline and Budget:
Paul has already made a good contact with a polymer expert at the University of New Hampshire. This prof has confirmed the soundness of the idea -- i.e., that the SafetyCurtain will work! He's suggested that a newer polymer might work even better than Kevlar, has offered to put Paul in touch with a mechanical engineer (to help design the springy attachments) and will serve as a materials science consultant once the project gets going. Paul's also made contact with a local policeman -- who gave him an old vest to take apart and has offered to use the police shooting range to do informal tests of early prototypes.
This IndieGoGo campaign is meant to fund Research & Development to capitalize on the ideas and planning done so far. The steps to be taken are pretty clear ... but we have no way of knowing how much some of these steps will cost. Converting the provisional patent to a full, regular patent will cost $10-15K (according to the Internet). Materials for experiments? Consulting fees? Prototyping? Lab testing and NIJ certification of the final product? Setting up for initial production? Neither of us has experience with this sort of thing -- not even enough to make truly sensible estimates of the expenses entailed. However, the campaign goal -- if we reach it -- should be enough to fund us all the way through R&D and into some kind of limited production! Please consider making a contribution!!
By the way -- although it's really quite premature -- we plan to go into production in Arkansas. That's where Lynnie lives ... and she'll be in charge of this phase of things -- finding a building for the factory, buying equipment, hiring and supervising workers. Lynnie's plan is to hire workers who have been in rehab -- who often have trouble finding jobs and are thrown back into the same conditions which caused their problems in the first place. By paying a good wage and treating them fairly, we can help them have a good chance to turn their lives around -- while manufacturing a product entirely within the USA!
* * * * * * * *

FAQs
What will the SafetyCurtain look like when it's not in use?
When retracted, the SafetyCurtain will reside in a box-like housing ... bolted to a wall of the classroom. The curtain itself will be completely out of sight. At present, the plan is to make this floor-to-ceiling housing in plain white. If it's painted in the color of the classroom walls, it will just look like the wall is jutting out there. Otherwise, it could be decorated in any way desired ...or serve as a bulletin board ... or etc..
OK. So it will be bolted to one wall and locked to another. But, why can't a shooter just kick it in? What makes it secure on all 4 sides?
The curtain is attached to the mechanism of the accordion door. This mechanism is then attached to the tracks on which it will glide. For the SafetyCurtain, these attachments will incorporate heavy-duty springs ... which will absorb the impact of a kick. Moreover, the high tensile strength of the Kevlar will resist a steel-toed boot as well as it does a bullet.
What will it cost? Won't it be too expensive for schools to buy?
The honest answer is: We really don't know what it will cost. Certain R&D tasks need to be accomplished before a good estimate might be given. Preliminary investigations into material costs have led us to believe that the SafetyCurtain can be produced and sold at a non-outrageous price! Both of us value frugality and efficiency and we both recognize how strained school budgets already are -- so we're aiming to offer the finished product at the lowest price possible.
Will it work?
Yes, it will! When Paul began to take his own idea seriously, one of the first things he did was to reach out to a polymer expert in the Materials Science department at University of New Hampshire -- to find out if the idea was feasible -- if it could work. The response was unequivocally positive! He made several helpful suggestions ... and is willing to act as a consultant once the project gets going. Moreover, once the SafetyCurtain is prototyped, it will go to one of the official labs that grant NIJ certifications ... and will have to meet the same standards as do bulletproof vests.
What sizes will it come in?
As we currently plan it: Any size you need. We'll probably offer stock lengths ... where the next length up will always work. Probably a few stock heights -- where the next height down will work (via flexible attachments to the ceiling, shielded by a protective apron). Unless a classroom is really enormous or has a cathedral ceiling, we'll be making a SafetyCurtain which will fit!
Is there any reason why these are restricted to classroom use? What if I want one for my office space at work?
Teachers and kids cowering in classrooms were what spurred the idea of the SafetyCurtain -- the need to give our kids the security they should have at school. But, there's no reason why they couldn't be installed in other places. Flexible track even opens the possibility of enclosing individual cubicles.
How far away do the kids have to be from the curtain so they don't get hurt?
It will only be necessary that no one be leaning directly against the SafetyCurtain. Otherwise, students and teachers can move freely within the protected area of the room.
Will the lock hold ... or can it be shot off?
The lock will be on the protected side of the SafetyCurtain, so it can't be shot off. It will be something simple -- like a padlock which hangs on the wall near the hasp which will get locked to the deployed curtain.
Will the SafetyCurtain protect all the kids in a school?
Sadly, no. They'll only protect the kids in the rooms which have them. Moreover, people in the room where a shooter starts a rampage might not have much opportunity to get behind the barrier, even if they have one. The benefits of the SafetyCurtain are for those who aren't in the opening line of fire.
* * * * * * * *

Who we are:

Lynnie Bat-Abba:  I'm a Nurse and a Professor of English, but my heart is with my children and grandchildren. My sister and I are raising her two small grandsons – having moved to a farm in the mountains of Arkansas, where we hope to keep them safe. Eight of my nine grandchildren are being home-schooled, keeping them out of reach to those selfish lunatics who shoot little kids. But, this option isn't open to everyone.
My nursing experience of over 20 years has put me in direct contact with all ages, but my primary interest has been Hospice and the care of very small children with severe disabilities. Many of these children are enrolled in special education within public schools. They are the most defenseless of all in a shooting situation.
I was excited by the idea of the SafetyCurtain because I know the pain of losing a child. At least I know my daughter died quietly, not screaming in fear and pain. No parent should have to suffer the unending loss of a child – but, when they are murdered,  there is no peace or restitution which can erase the anguish. Implementing a way to protect our little ones is a way of doing our best to care for them. Sending our children to school shouldn't cause us to panic. We must be proactive. The SafetyCurtain would, at very least, alleviate some fear ... and at best, bring our babies home to us safe and sound -- not to bury, but to hold and cherish!
 

Paul Fischler: By education, I'm a philosopher. In the long-ago, I taught the subject at Cornell and a few other places. By nature, though, I'm an entrepreneur and "inventor" -- trying to think up simple solutions to some of the problems of ordinary life. Sadly, school shootings have become one such "ordinary" problem -- and the news reports I heard prompted the idea for the SafetyCurtain.
I'll be in charge of all the Research & Development ... and have already acquired more knowledge of guns and ballistic materials than I ever expected to need! I'll be working with a polymer expert (to determine the best material for the SafetyCurtain and the best way of using it) and a mechanical engineer (to design the springy attachments which will keep the SafetyCurtain secure) -- both faculty members at UNH.
My aim here is to create a product -- at the lowest cost possible -- which will protect our kids from flying bullets ... and from the trauma of hiding under desks or in closets while some homicidal maniac attacks their building. I can't think of how to stop the loonies from launching such attacks -- but keeping kids safe seems doable!
* * * * * * * *

If you can contribute, that's wonderful! But, that's not the only way you can help get this project off the ground. You can -- if you would be so kind -- spread the word as widely as possible in tweets, blogs, forums, emails and your social networks ... and by using the IndieGoGo share tools -- helping us make some noise about this useful product. We all want our kids to feel safe in school. You can be instrumental in bringing that about! Please do what you can. Thank you!!
* * * * * * * *
For those who contribute $25, we will thank you with your own Genuine Certificate of Goodness ... with your name in place of Jennifer's, of course. Properly framed, it would occupy the same space and carry the same weight as almost any diploma! Please contribute!

story:
Me, on the right, and Fernanda, on the left, on our trip to the forest by my project,                                                                 Reconexão Amazônia     

I am environmental journalist and educator from Brazil, I am truly committed in doing my best to help protecting the Amazon Rainforest. You will find more details about the 8 years of my work for the forest on the video above.  Charles Eisenstein, Satish Kumar, John Croft and professors Philip Franses and Stephan Harding are some of the amazing people that understand the importance of this studies to me and my work.

Last year, I started the Reconnection Amazon Rainforest Project, where I give classes and talks about the forest to youth and adults. I also take people to the forest and do deep ecology with them, so they will be able to open their hearts to reconnect emotionally with it. I believe that the affection between people and the Amazon is very effective and a way of saving it from destruction, specially when it is accompanied by scientific information.

The idea of applying for a Masters degree in Holistc Science at Schumacher College came as a suggestion from Satish Kumar. He is a 78 year old indian activist, editor of Ressurgence magazine and founder of the college. I applied, was accepted and got a bursary + my savings and a first crowdfunding campaign, I raised almost everything I needed to study at Schumacher College as a master student. 

Currently and officially, I am doing the Post Graduate. To be able to upgrade to the Ms.c, I need + 4,900 pounds by December. The total amount of the course is £ 22,521. 

This is the experience, knowledge and education I need to be more prepared. The Ms. c in Holistic Science enables us to use rationality as well as intuition to go deeper in our relationship with nature and gives us very good tools that will certainly be very helpful to my work.

Last official data from Brazil, published by Inpe, shows an increase of 69% in the deforestation rate from 2014-2015, the worst in 6 years. The indigenous and the whole life within the forest are being seriously threatened by mining, cattle ranging, cutting of illegal wood . big infra structure projects and so on.

Through many different experiences, I´ve been working to keep the Amazon alive. With your support, I´ll be more prepared to keep walking this path. By supporting me, you will be help me protecting the forest. I am 100% aware of what I am saying and of my responsibility with you and your more than valuable contribution. 

Gratitude!

Special thanks to all more than 100 supporters that made possible my arrival at the school, through so many different ways. Also, gratitude to my family, to Schumacher College for believing in me since the very first moment and to our beloved Amazon, that brought me here.

If you want to know more about my work and the Amazon, please, visit:

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/supporting-t...

Reconexao Amazonia - http://www.reconexaoamazonia.com/

Thank you so much!

story:
What is 3 Day Startup Berkeley?

  • As a team of UC Berkeley undergraduates, we set out to make entrepreneurship not just a buzzword but a reality to students of all majors with 3 Day Startup.
  • Over 3 days, 40 participants purposely selected from different backgrounds, skill sets and experience pitch their ideas, vote for the best ones and collaborate to create actual products and services.
  • At 3 Day Startup, participants fully immerse in the process of creating their company, experiencing first-hand the anxieties of pitching, market testing and meeting deadlines for a prototype. 

  • The experience, in all its intensity, challenges them and allows them to learn.
  • We are NOT a hackathon. Our value lies in providing the means with which the experienced can reach higher goals and the novice can have a chance to be part of a project and experience entrepreneurship. 
  • There is no competition or prize. Rather, we focus on: 

                                                Creativity through diversity

                                            Innovation through collaboration

                                              Learning through experiencing

  • When you help us, you are helping a frustrated body of students with NO technical background and the talented business minds with ZERO connections to the technicians find a dependable, passionate team that could give wings to ideas with a potential to change the world.


What We Need & What You Get 

With your support, we will be able to:

  • Provide enough food and snacks for our student entrepreneurs over 3 days
  • Allow us to give perks that make 3 Day Start memorable for participants!
  • Cover the costs of facilitating 3 Day Startup, including transportation and expenses for our facilitator
Your contribution will be recognized at our program! You will get the chance to come by and see 3DS in action, and you will get priority consideration for involvement in our future programs.

The Reach and Success of the Program

  • Past: 200+ Programs at universities in US, Israel, Chile, China, Thailand, Spain, Netherlands, Germany, France, Portugal, Qatar, Ghana, and Columbia.


  • Real Results: 90 companies launched that have collectively raised $70M
  • 34 companies accepted into incubators/accelerators such as Y Combinator, TechStarts, and DreamIt Venture.


The Impact at Berkeley What does this mean for UC Berkeley? 

When you help us, you

  • Push forward a program that isn't a competition but an idea generating and collaborative effort towards innovation.
  • Provide an opportunity for students not just at UC Berkeley but those around the Bay Area to go outside of their areas of expertise to test their ideas.
  • Push for education and innovation through transparency and teamwork.

When and Where is Fall 2015 3DS Berkeley

  • Dates and Times:
    November 6th, 5:00 PM - 10:00 PM
    November 7th, 9:00 AM - 10:00 PM
    November 8th, 9:00 AM ~ 7:00 PM
  • Location: NextSpace Berkeley Coworking Space - 2081 Center Street, Berkeley 94704
SHOUT OUT to NEXTSPACE for generously providing us with the venue!!!


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Like and Review us and our Proud Sponsors on Facebook!
  • BECOME A MENTOR to help our budding entrepreneurs! Please email us at berkeley@3daystartup.org
  • SHARE this page with your friends and colleagues!
  • STOP BY and hear our pitches on Day 3! Learn more HERE.

Thank you very much for your time and support! Sign up for our mailing list, we will keep you updated!!

story:
Who is VOVA?

VOVA is a 501(c)3 non-profit, founded in 2008 to create a worldwide forum for community-based research in vocal and verbal art performances.  We are an international network of scholars in anthropology, linguistics, and literature working with endangered language speakers, students, teachers, and artists.  Our research promotes the arts of spoken word and voice in their diverse and infinite manifestations in cultures across the planet. 

(Pakouene François Goïta, Bwa story-teller, recorded by Irénée Diarra, disc-jockey and program entertainer at Radio Parana, in San, Mali, 2005. To Mr. Goïta's left, Tan'ian Dembélé and Wurowe Keïta, community recognized storytellers. Photo taken by Prof. Cécile Leguy.)


Our Goals and Our Donors

Our goal of $50K will allow us to develop custom-designed, secure interactive tools (a text-editor, databases, basic forums, uploads, etc) for our researchers and associates to work together on a single platform for the very first time!  

With your help, we will also develop the VOVA Speech Genres Gallery with an open-source, informative database available to the public. Researchers, language teachers, and community language speakers will be able to safely pool data reflecting the practice of speech styles and genres enjoyed in communities around the world. Visitors to our website will be able to view transcriptions, translations, photos, videos, and descriptive texts depicting community vocal and verbal art performances.

The Speech Genres Gallery will provide a cornerstone for the VOVA Exchange Platform that will offer state-of-the-art tools for:

  • editing and annotating oral discourse from community performances
  • crowdsourcing translations of edited texts
  • compiling descriptive, interpretive, and analytical data in open source databases and wikis
  • uploading audio and video recordings of community practices of vocal and verbal art styles, genres, and performances
  • educational tutorials
  • social media forums related to language, poetic speaking, and culture

To show our deep appreciation for the generosity of our donors, we have designed graphics for quality postcards and t-shirts that we hope you will enjoy.  These graphics reflect speech genres gathered from our studies and from verbal artistry shared by community language speakers. Donors may also enjoy the CD, Dedicated, by The Stoney Creek Singers, the Tutelo-Saponi group featured in our video. These perks were designed to inspire a fun way of thinking about language styles and speech genres and promote understanding and appreciation of poetic speech as it unfolds in everyday life. 


VOVA Genres T-Shirt design:

(Choose between unisex t-shirt made , sizes S, M, L, XL,and XXL;  OR a woman's t-shirt, sizes S, M, L, XL, and XXL.  Both t-shirts made with 100% certified organic ring-spun cotton, in navy blue).

Verbal Art Postcards:
The proverb is a genre commonly performed in verbal exchange in many regions of the world.  We have compiled proverbs in Akan-Twi (Ghana), Boomu (Mali), Hausa (Nigeria), and Teke (Republic of Congo), along with a Malagasy kabary, and a Tamil thirrukural for a collection of 6 Verbal Art postcards.   These cards are made with the finest quality custom printing on 100% cotton rag, both acid free and lignin free for long-term archival use.


The Stoney Creek Singers CD, Dedicated :
For an ear-pleaser, we are also offering our donors the CD entitled Dedicated by The Stoney Creek Singers, the Tutelo-Saponi singers from North Carolina who appear in our video.

"Now in their 21st year, The Stoney Creek Singers have traveled from coast to coast singing at some of the most prestigious powwows across North America."

VOVA logo t-shirt: 

_________________________


Stylistic Diversity t-shirt:

(Unisex t-shirts, sizes S, M, L, XL,and XXL with 100% cotton, white with black lettering). 


Verbal Art Research, More than a Symbolic Impact

Poetic use of language in everyday speech is a universal practice.  Its concrete manifestations are, however, specific to individual languages and individual speakers. Sharing poetic voices across cultures serves to strengthen cultural identities, promote diversity, and develop human resources for world peace.

Massive amounts of knowledge and information are transmitted orally everyday, and protected by cultural use of mnemonic devices such as formulaic phrasing, rhyme, speech rhythms, and many other stylistic devices embedded in speech practice.  But it is the very practice of verbal art performance that interests us most. 

Jean-Louis' painting "Palabres" beautifully captures the powerful force of face-to-face verbal exchange.

Vocal and verbal art scholars have demonstrated the artful expressivity of hundreds of languages.  We know that rhetorical and stylistic use of language provides one of the most valuable resources held by a community.  The preservation of spoken language arts for future generations is absolutely crucial. 

Community-based linguistic education has proven to be a sound and sustainable tool for building cross-cultural communication skills, understanding, and mutual respect. We are convinced that increased attention to the values and resources of vocal and verbal art will lead to a improved understanding of the importance of multiple world views for cultivating humanity.

Moreover, scientists have clearly demonstrated the link between the planet's biodiversity and language diversity. Gorenflo et al. provide "detailed global data showing the geographic extent of more than 6,900 languages, recently compiled by Global Mapping International, to analyze linguistic diversity in regions containing much of Earth's biological diversity, biodiversity hotspots and high biodiversity wilderness areas" Gorenflo et al., 2009.  

(Federico Calapucha tells a group of students about the connection of a forest tree to his ancestors. Amazonian Kichwa language. Sapo Rumi, Ecuador. Photo by Michael Uzendoski.)

Protection of nature's ecosystems in biodiversity hotspots has long been a cultural priority for indigenous communities.  Honoring their traditions and learning from indigenous lifestyles requires more than documenting linguistic structures and biological taxonomies. It is absolutely crucial to respect and maintain the life conditions and cultures of communities that have prospered in their cohabitation with other life forms.  


Important Challenges

VOVA faces three major challenges to our ambitions:  1) our unconventional approach to language; 2) working across distinctly different academic traditions; and 3) working with community language speakers, not as subjects, but as partners. We view these challenges, however, not as obstacles, but as principles and opportunities for reaching new horizons.

The unique contribution of VOVA to the growing efforts at valorizing indigenous languages and cultures has been to focus on the esthetic principles of language practice as a sustaining factor of cultural behavior, values, and resources.  Poetic practices in everyday language use may seem esoteric or even superfluous to policy makers and even some academics.  Oral literature is viewed by many literature scholars as inferior to the written word.  Stylistic approaches to verbal exchange have remained on the peripheries of core curricula in linguistics and anthropology departments. 

Scholars devoted to responsible and accessible study of stylized speech practices in community life often remain marginalized in their university departments, many never even benefitting from a tenured position.  VOVA has responded to this situation by reaching out to scholars, both institutional and non-institutional, and building an international network for sharing methodologies and pooling resources. It is our ambition to create a foundation to provide research funds to researchers and to graduate students to advance institutional study of community vocal and verbal arts.

The international status of VOVA is a major strength of our initiative despite the complexities of merging age-old academic traditions that can often get lost in translation. One of the major undertakings of VOVA in overcoming these barriers has been to establish a multi-disciplinary nomenclature in English and in French.  An annotated bibliography is another of the tools that we will build onto the VOVA Exchange Platform as it progresses.

Successful partnership between academics and community language speakers is undoubtedly what makes the VOVA challenge such an exciting and fulfilling adventure.  Linguists and anthropologists have progressively moved from detached observers of language use and social life to cross-cultural diplomats. Partnership between academics and community-leaders as mutual stake-holders is a fundamental aspect to the very organization of VOVA. 

Diversity is a fundamental policy of VOVA, from the administrative level to the scientific level.  Our Board of Directors includes members from the Chinook Nation, from the Confederated Tribes of Grande Ronde, from the Kiowa Tribe, from the Chippewa Tribe, from Mali, and from the Republic of Congo. VOVA Editorial and Advisory Boards and close associates include scholars from 16 nations, including 10 developing countries. Our members handle materials in over 50 languages, either as fluent community-based speakers or experienced field scholars.

There can be no doubt that decision-making amongst such a wide representation of world citizens can become tedious and painstaking.  It is, however, just this diversity in world views and esthetic values that makes VOVA a forward-moving and promising adventure. 

(Donovan, Mohammed, and Bevelyn share their artistic visions at a VOVA gathering in Los Angeles.  Photo by Catharine Mason.)

Ways You Can Help

We appreciate your taking time to read about our goals and our work, and spreading the word!  All donations to VOVA are tax-deductible and will help us to build our platform and hire research assistants for compiling a rich, multilingual archive from the work of our members and associates.  The design of our platform is fully scalable, meaning that we can move forward with lesser and greater amounts of funding as it is made available.

We realize that it is not always the right time for people to make donations.  But we hope to keep you on board while we build our platform and connect with new communities and researchers.  

We encourage you to continue to explore language styles and genres, and to learn about language diversity and language preservation by consulting the VOVA Website regularly.  You can learn more about VOVA and lend your support by liking our Facebook page, Crossing Language Borders, by following us on LinkedIn, and by joining our YouTube channel.

And please SHARE OUR INDIEGOGO CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN with friends, relatives, and associates!
story_txt:
Who is VOVA? 
VOVA is a 501(c)3 non-profit, founded in 2008 to create a worldwide forum for community-based research in vocal and verbal art performances.  We are an international network of scholars in anthropology, linguistics, and literature working with endangered language speakers, students, teachers, and artists.  Our research promotes the arts of spoken word and voice in their diverse and infinite manifestations in cultures across the planet. 



(Pakouene François Goïta, Bwa story-teller, recorded by Irénée Diarra, disc-jockey and program entertainer at Radio Parana, in San, Mali, 2005. To Mr. Goïta's left, Tan'ian Dembélé and Wurowe Keïta, community recognized storytellers. Photo taken by Prof. Cécile Leguy.)

   Our Goals and Our Donors Our goal of $50K will allow us to develop custom-designed, secure interactive tools (a text-editor, databases, basic forums, uploads, etc) for our researchers and associates to work together on a single platform for the very first time!  
With your help, we will also develop the VOVA Speech Genres Gallery with an open-source, informative database available to the public. Researchers, language teachers, and community language speakers will be able to safely pool data reflecting the practice of speech styles and genres enjoyed in communities around the world. Visitors to our website will be able to view transcriptions, translations, photos, videos, and descriptive texts depicting community vocal and verbal art performances.
The Speech Genres Gallery will provide a cornerstone for the VOVA Exchange Platform that will offer state-of-the-art tools for:


editing and annotating oral discourse from community performances
crowdsourcing translations of edited texts
compiling descriptive, interpretive, and analytical data in open source databases and wikis
uploading audio and video recordings of community practices of vocal and verbal art styles, genres, and performances
educational tutorials
social media forums related to language, poetic speaking, and culture

To show our deep appreciation for the generosity of our donors, we have designed graphics for quality postcards and t-shirts that we hope you will enjoy.  These graphics reflect speech genres gathered from our studies and from verbal artistry shared by community language speakers. Donors may also enjoy the CD, Dedicated, by The Stoney Creek Singers, the Tutelo-Saponi group featured in our video. These perks were designed to inspire a fun way of thinking about language styles and speech genres and promote understanding and appreciation of poetic speech as it unfolds in everyday life. 

VOVA Genres T-Shirt design:



(Choose between unisex t-shirt made , sizes S, M, L, XL,and XXL;  OR a woman's t-shirt, sizes S, M, L, XL, and XXL.  Both t-shirts made with 100% certified organic ring-spun cotton, in navy blue).


Verbal Art Postcards:

The proverb is a genre commonly performed in verbal exchange in many regions of the world.  We have compiled proverbs in Akan-Twi (Ghana), Boomu (Mali), Hausa (Nigeria), and Teke (Republic of Congo), along with a Malagasy kabary, and a Tamil thirrukural for a collection of 6 Verbal Art postcards.   These cards are made with the finest quality custom printing on 100% cotton rag, both acid free and lignin free for long-term archival use.



The Stoney Creek Singers CD, Dedicated :

For an ear-pleaser, we are also offering our donors the CD entitled Dedicated by The Stoney Creek Singers, the Tutelo-Saponi singers from North Carolina who appear in our video.




"Now in their 21st year, The Stoney Creek Singers have traveled from coast to coast singing at some of the most prestigious powwows across North America."


VOVA logo t-shirt: 




_________________________

Stylistic Diversity t-shirt:


(Unisex t-shirts, sizes S, M, L, XL,and XXL with 100% cotton, white with black lettering). 

Verbal Art Research, More than a Symbolic Impact Poetic use of language in everyday speech is a universal practice.  Its concrete manifestations are, however, specific to individual languages and individual speakers. Sharing poetic voices across cultures serves to strengthen cultural identities, promote diversity, and develop human resources for world peace.
Massive amounts of knowledge and information are transmitted orally everyday, and protected by cultural use of mnemonic devices such as formulaic phrasing, rhyme, speech rhythms, and many other stylistic devices embedded in speech practice.  But it is the very practice of verbal art performance that interests us most. 


Jean-Louis' painting "Palabres" beautifully captures the powerful force of face-to-face verbal exchange.
Vocal and verbal art scholars have demonstrated the artful expressivity of hundreds of languages.  We know that rhetorical and stylistic use of language provides one of the most valuable resources held by a community.  The preservation of spoken language arts for future generations is absolutely crucial. 
Community-based linguistic education has proven to be a sound and sustainable tool for building cross-cultural communication skills, understanding, and mutual respect. We are convinced that increased attention to the values and resources of vocal and verbal art will lead to a improved understanding of the importance of multiple world views for cultivating humanity.
Moreover, scientists have clearly demonstrated the link between the planet's biodiversity and language diversity. Gorenflo et al. provide "detailed global data showing the geographic extent of more than 6,900 languages, recently compiled by Global Mapping International, to analyze linguistic diversity in regions containing much of Earth's biological diversity, biodiversity hotspots and high biodiversity wilderness areas" Gorenflo et al., 2009.  



(Federico Calapucha tells a group of students about the connection of a forest tree to his ancestors. Amazonian Kichwa language. Sapo Rumi, Ecuador. Photo by Michael Uzendoski.)
Protection of nature's ecosystems in biodiversity hotspots has long been a cultural priority for indigenous communities.  Honoring their traditions and learning from indigenous lifestyles requires more than documenting linguistic structures and biological taxonomies. It is absolutely crucial to respect and maintain the life conditions and cultures of communities that have prospered in their cohabitation with other life forms.  

Important Challenges
 VOVA faces three major challenges to our ambitions:  1) our unconventional approach to language; 2) working across distinctly different academic traditions; and 3) working with community language speakers, not as subjects, but as partners. We view these challenges, however, not as obstacles, but as principles and opportunities for reaching new horizons.
The unique contribution of VOVA to the growing efforts at valorizing indigenous languages and cultures has been to focus on the esthetic principles of language practice as a sustaining factor of cultural behavior, values, and resources.  Poetic practices in everyday language use may seem esoteric or even superfluous to policy makers and even some academics.  Oral literature is viewed by many literature scholars as inferior to the written word.  Stylistic approaches to verbal exchange have remained on the peripheries of core curricula in linguistics and anthropology departments. 
Scholars devoted to responsible and accessible study of stylized speech practices in community life often remain marginalized in their university departments, many never even benefitting from a tenured position.  VOVA has responded to this situation by reaching out to scholars, both institutional and non-institutional, and building an international network for sharing methodologies and pooling resources. It is our ambition to create a foundation to provide research funds to researchers and to graduate students to advance institutional study of community vocal and verbal arts.
The international status of VOVA is a major strength of our initiative despite the complexities of merging age-old academic traditions that can often get lost in translation. One of the major undertakings of VOVA in overcoming these barriers has been to establish a multi-disciplinary nomenclature in English and in French.  An annotated bibliography is another of the tools that we will build onto the VOVA Exchange Platform as it progresses.
Successful partnership between academics and community language speakers is undoubtedly what makes the VOVA challenge such an exciting and fulfilling adventure.  Linguists and anthropologists have progressively moved from detached observers of language use and social life to cross-cultural diplomats. Partnership between academics and community-leaders as mutual stake-holders is a fundamental aspect to the very organization of VOVA. 
Diversity is a fundamental policy of VOVA, from the administrative level to the scientific level.  Our Board of Directors includes members from the Chinook Nation, from the Confederated Tribes of Grande Ronde, from the Kiowa Tribe, from the Chippewa Tribe, from Mali, and from the Republic of Congo. VOVA Editorial and Advisory Boards and close associates include scholars from 16 nations, including 10 developing countries. Our members handle materials in over 50 languages, either as fluent community-based speakers or experienced field scholars.
There can be no doubt that decision-making amongst such a wide representation of world citizens can become tedious and painstaking.  It is, however, just this diversity in world views and esthetic values that makes VOVA a forward-moving and promising adventure. 




(Donovan, Mohammed, and Bevelyn share their artistic visions at a VOVA gathering in Los Angeles.  Photo by Catharine Mason.)


Ways You Can Help
 We appreciate your taking time to read about our goals and our work, and spreading the word!  All donations to VOVA are tax-deductible and will help us to build our platform and hire research assistants for compiling a rich, multilingual archive from the work of our members and associates.  The design of our platform is fully scalable, meaning that we can move forward with lesser and greater amounts of funding as it is made available.
We realize that it is not always the right time for people to make donations.  But we hope to keep you on board while we build our platform and connect with new communities and researchers.  
We encourage you to continue to explore language styles and genres, and to learn about language diversity and language preservation by consulting the VOVA Website regularly.  You can learn more about VOVA and lend your support by liking our Facebook page, Crossing Language Borders, by following us on LinkedIn, and by joining our YouTube channel.
And please SHARE OUR INDIEGOGO CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN with friends, relatives, and associates!

story:
Short Summary

Forest Grove School Preservation is dedicated to telling the story of rural education through the historic rehabilitation of Forest Grove School No. 5, an iconic Iowa one-room schoolhouse.  The transformation began in 2012.  Our current goal is to raise $5000 to begin building the impressive bell tower, which will accommodate the original bell in our possession.  Best photo documentation of our progress can be found at https://www.facebook.com/ForestGroveSchoolPrese....  Historic photos can be viewed on our website at www.forestgroveschool.org.

story:
Short Summary

The summer of 2016 will celebrate the 25th anniversary of Ukiah's Sundays in the Park concert series. Over the past 24 years we have hosted 145 free concerts and 158 bands to over 350,000 attendees. The series is free, brings a wide range of music to the park, is accessible to people of all ages and demographics creating the capacity for the citizens of Ukiah to come together as a community in one common setting.

We need help with this silver anniversary year with the costs of bringing a summer of great bands in the 25th year. The more funds we have, the better the bands are…it's that simple. The series is non-profit, we receive no funds from the city government and all of our donations in the past have come from LOCAL businesses who believe in the power of music and the ability to grow community. Funding has decreased over the last few years in our community due to the many events, organizations and benefits that need funding these days. We are aiming at some great talent this year and would like to have a star studded lineup to celebrate the 25th year so we are asking the public to help.

If you love music, if you love dancing, if you love our community we’re sure you would love to be a partner!

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking the community to donate $15,000 collectively. This money will go towards the bands for Sundays in the Park 2016 Concert Series. 

We have several different partnership tiers which include some amazing gifts for you as our partner.

The Impact

Last year we experienced a 25% decrease in sponsorship money due to the economy. To hold the Sunday in the Park standard where it has been the last 24 years we need your help.

Since day one our series has been free and has been our contribution to community building in the Ukiah area. We are reaching out this year to ask for help in celebrating our 25th year as well as keeping this amazing tradition alive and thriving.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can give money but that doesn’t mean that you can’t help! Please spread the word about this campaign by sharing on your social media outlets!

story:
HELP US GET LEGAL STATUS

My name is VO THI MY LINH. I was born and raised in Vietnam. I am 26 years old and I have co-authored ten books of short stories for teenagers. I published my first novel late last year. It received good reviews from many critics and will be made into a movie soon. My second novel will be published next month. 

In  my first year of college, I wrote a letter to the Chairman of Binh Phuoc Province. The letter was successful in persuading him to give scholarships to poor students. After graduating from college, I worked for Trend & Life magazine in 2012 and 2013 and quickly became an excellent reporter. In November 2014, I became more prominent after writing a letter to the Minister of Education. In this letter I advocated an improvment in English educational programs in my developing country.

I started to write when I was a child. However, the writing I first practiced was the divorce agreements for my parents. I cannot recall the number of times I wrote different versions or the number of tears that ran down my face. I am certain that no words can describe the pain of a daughter who had to write divorce agreements for her parents. As a girl who grew up in a house where I witnessed domestic violence many times and where the crash of breaking furniture when my father got drunk was a frightening nightmare, I admitted that trying to help my mother get a divorce was the only way I could protect her.

Surprisingly, my mom chose to stay with my father. When I grew up, I realized that many women in my hometown suffered from domestic violence. Many of them were reluctant to divorce their husbands, as they were afraid of people judging them. Moreover, when they looked at others who were in the same situation, they probably assumed that domestic violence was normal. From that point on, I understood that poverty and a lack of education were the main reasons why women and children had to suffer domestic violence in my country.

One and a half years ago, I decided to quit a good job to travel. My principal aim was to find a way to communicate with foreigners to improve my English skills. However, to be honest, it was more because I wanted to break out of the imaginary prison I was in. I did not want to end up like my mother. I wanted to tell everybody who was suffering domestic violence that they have a right to live differently. I became well known after surviving and writing about an avalanche in Nepal, which killed at least 43 of 168 trekkers on Annapurna Mountain. 

That fateful trip took me to many wonderful things and finally I am here - the founder of the Volunteer House Vietnam project. The project is based on a very simple premise: free accommodation for foreign travelers in Vietnam in exchange for free English lessons for children.

With the help of many dedicated volunteers, I run this program with no funding. I have been devoting many hours a day to this project because I do not want English to be a tool for success for just those who have money. Also, I believe that English is a very important way for the poor to have a more cohesive life. It can help them become more aware that human rights are not only the right to eat and to live but also the right to be protected and to pursue happiness. 

The Volunteer House Project, after a year, has proven its success, and now operates in more than 18 cities where people are willing to let us use their dwellings as classrooms for free. As of now, more than 2,500 members from all over the country have registered to become volunteers for the project; 4 English classes in Ho Chi Minh City and 4 English classes in Hanoi have been established. Volunteer House Vietnam also has teamed up with AIESEC, GLC (two international organizations providing young people with leadership development and cross-cultural global internships) in HCMC to bring foreign students to Vietnam to undertake their internships  with our project. 

My only financial support  for the time I spend on this project is from the sale of my novel. I haven't bought any new clothes in a year but I'm confident that a woman is still beautiful without make up because of what she is doing.

However, life is a struggle. To maintain this project, we need to get legal status from the government.  In Vietnam, it costs at least 50,000 USD to get legal status as a non-profit organization (NPO). Also, we need funding to rent a house for travelers those who provide free English lessons to the poor and homeless children. We provide free accommodation to travelers in exchange for free English instruction for these children. Most of the houses that have been offered a room of their house for us to use are inconvenient for travelers because they are pretty far from the classes.

I  hope that you can make a donation to help us maintain this project. VHV does good things and with your help we can do even more. 

Your contribution helps us understand that none of us are alone in this world. 

Thank you so much from the bottom of my heart.

Sincerely,

Linh Vo - the Founder & CEO of Volunteer House Vietnam

Verify us at:

http://volunteerhousevietnam.org

http://vietnamnews.vn/sunday/features/280227/travellers-take-their-time-to-give-something-back.html

http://tuoitrenews.vn/features/30935/nepal-bliz...

https://www.facebook.com/volunteerhousevietnam....

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z3lW-3VGXpQ

http://www.values.com/your-inspirational-storie...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5sU9JoqzTxQ
