campaign_city: Ho Chi Minh & Ha Noi, Vietnam

story:
We believe that everyone should have access to the best tools and support to determine their own path, throughout and beyond education. With no REAL careers guidance system in place Honest Voice brings together careers, life and education support into one technology solution to inspire and support future generations. We are building a limitless generation and we need your help.

Honest Voice is an organisation built to empower and prepare young people to take control of their future.

No more wasted potential, no more self-doubt, just endless opportunity. We want to help form a limitless generation.

The current careers system does not provide young people with the purposeful and practical careers, life and education support they need to achieve their full potential or make informed decisions about their future. Students are often underprepared for life beyond education, and this can affect their future and limit their career options.

We provide options.

 

How?

Our online portal has been designed and structured into four key sections to challenge the mind-set and empower our members to:               

                             

“Find it”

Explore a broad range of careers and industries through our ‘REAL guides’ and ‘REAL vlogs’. Our guides and vlogs are prepared by people who are experienced in the roles and industries we will showcase.

Our vlogs and guides will provide our members with a true reflection of:

  • The day to day duties of each role
  • The skills they would gain
  • What they are required to do to secure a similar role
  • What career progression opportunities are available

We also provide alternative career routes and options so that our members are always prepared for any route their journey takes.   

 

Build a “Toolkit”

Find their strengths and discover their transferable skills through workshops, online support and short tests.

Young people often struggle to identify and articulate their strengths and overlook the skills they build in hobbies and extra circular activities. They also often overlook the key transferable skills that are vital in developing who they are as workers and leaders when they enter the working world.

                                                                       

Recognise the “Real Stuff”                                                               

We will showcase what the textbooks don’t teach young people about their future; building the soft skills required to achieve individual success in both life and education.

Our Real Stuff section highlights the skills that are so important throughout life but are often neglected. Skills such as effective communication, how to find a mentor, top tips for interviewing and how to manage challenging relationships.

 

Develop a stronger and more positive self (“You”)                                              

We will support our members in developing resilience and a stronger and more positive, mind set.

Wellbeing is at the very heart of Honest Voice. We want to ensure that our members are equipped with the right tools to build a strong foundation for a limitless life. This includes topics such as confidence, self-doubt, resilience and stress.

 

Jobs!

Honest Voice is committed to preparing and connecting our limitless generation to the workplace. With support from a broad range of successful businesses we will showcase internships, apprenticeships, graduate roles and work experience opportunities – enabling the leaders of tomorrow to be supported and inspired by the leaders of today.

 

Our Pledge

Honest Voice is pledging to Empower, Prepare and Lead young people to unleash their true potential. By 2021 we aim to be supporting the majority of schools, colleges, universities and youth community groups across the United Kingdom. We pledge to connect with every young person that needs our help. We will level the playing field by supporting our members with the knowledge required to succeed.

We will build a truly Limitless Generation. 

 

               

 

What we need

We believe that everyone knows someone who would benefit from the Honest Voice platform. For example, your child, niece, nephew, friend or sibling. We are here to offer our support. However we need your help to reach as many young people as possible.

Honest Voice needs to raise £25,000 to fund our growth and launch in September 2018. The money that we raise will be spent on building our platform, improving our content and reaching young people across the UK.

We will launch building on pre-established relationships with schools, colleges, youth community groups and universities.

To grow, to be self-sustaining, and to ensure we build our member base across the UK, Honest Voice will offer its premium content at a low cost monthly or annual subscription. (less than your monthly Netflix membership).

                                                                                                                                  

Who are we?

Honest Voice has been able to build momentum to date through an unwavering level of support from companies, schools, individuals and team members, and we are forever grateful for all of the support.

We would like to thank everyone for the continued support they have shown Honest Voice, in particular the Honest Voice team who volunteer their time to make Honest Voice a true success.

 

Team Leads

 

                         

Charlene Brown 

Founder

 

         

Joel Westley                                                          

Founding Member                                                             

 

                             

Himal Patel 

Founding Member 

 

 

Dominique Walker                                                              

Founding Member                                                       

 

                              

Jasmine Shell 

Founding Member 

 

Sophie Richardson

Founding Member                                 

 

And the wider team... 

  • Adobea Atsrefi 
  • Alice Bjorkdahl
  • Dawn Whyte
  • Katherine Noble
  • Laurielle De Boer
  • Malachi Ferguson 
  • Reha Begum
  • Rodney Williams 
  • Shalina Rahman 
  • Shaunée James
  • Sian Johnson-James  
  • Whitney Joseph 

 

FAQ's

What will our Platform include?

Our platform will be an interactive website and we plan in 2019 to develop an app to amplify accessibility. At Honest Voice our sole focus is to  empower, prepare and support all of our members in all aspects of life, from careers to protecting the mindset. We have therefore split our platform into four key sections that offer a substantive full cycle support system; These sections are Find It, Toolkit, Real Stuff and You.

 

Are we a company or a charity?

Honest Voice is a limited company with a social purpose and we chose this option as it allows us to have a much greater impact and be self sustaining. This allows us to continue a high quality level of support without being affected by government funding constraints or cuts.  

 

How will we sustain ourselves as a company?

By operating a subscription model we can charge a very affordable membership fee for those who can pay, allowing us to expand our reach and invest in additional content and tools to better support our members. This will also allow us to reach those individuals who don't have the means to access Honest Voice on their own (failing schools, youth offending sites and community interest groups). Collectively we can make a huge difference to generations to come.

 

What is a Company with a Social Purpose?

We want to build a limitless generation and fundamentally evolve the careers, life and education support young people and their supporters. We want to change the outcomes for current and future generations. This is our purpose.

As mentioned above, Honest Voice is a private limited company and a for profit business. This does not change or diminish our social purpose. Our sole focus is not to sell a product but to offer our members the best opportunity and tools to achieve their dreams and to reach their career and life goals.  Being self sustaining allows us to have unlimited potential for growth.
story_txt:
We believe that everyone should have access to the best tools and support to determine their own path, throughout and beyond education. With no REAL careers guidance system in place Honest Voice brings together careers, life and education support into one technology solution to inspire and support future generations. We are building a limitless generation and we need your help.Honest Voice is an organisation built to empower and prepare young people to take control of their future.No more wasted potential, no more self-doubt, just endless opportunity. We want to help form a limitless generation.The current careers system does not provide young people with the purposeful and practical careers, life and education support they need to achieve their full potential or make informed decisions about their future. Students are often underprepared for life beyond education, and this can affect their future and limit their career options.We provide options. How?Our online portal has been designed and structured into four key sections to challenge the mind-set and empower our members to:                                            “Find it” Explore a broad range of careers and industries through our ‘REAL guides’ and ‘REAL vlogs’. Our guides and vlogs are prepared by people who are experienced in the roles and industries we will showcase. Our vlogs and guides will provide our members with a true reflection of:
The day to day duties of each role
The skills they would gain
What they are required to do to secure a similar role
What career progression opportunities are available
We also provide alternative career routes and options so that our members are always prepared for any route their journey takes.    Build a “Toolkit”Find their strengths and discover their transferable skills through workshops, online support and short tests. Young people often struggle to identify and articulate their strengths and overlook the skills they build in hobbies and extra circular activities. They also often overlook the key transferable skills that are vital in developing who they are as workers and leaders when they enter the working world.                                                                       Recognise the “Real Stuff”                                                               We will showcase what the textbooks don’t teach young people about their future; building the soft skills required to achieve individual success in both life and education. Our Real Stuff section highlights the skills that are so important throughout life but are often neglected. Skills such as effective communication, how to find a mentor, top tips for interviewing and how to manage challenging relationships. Develop a stronger and more positive self (“You”)                                              We will support our members in developing resilience and a stronger and more positive, mind set. Wellbeing is at the very heart of Honest Voice. We want to ensure that our members are equipped with the right tools to build a strong foundation for a limitless life. This includes topics such as confidence, self-doubt, resilience and stress. Jobs! Honest Voice is committed to preparing and connecting our limitless generation to the workplace. With support from a broad range of successful businesses we will showcase internships, apprenticeships, graduate roles and work experience opportunities – enabling the leaders of tomorrow to be supported and inspired by the leaders of today. Our Pledge Honest Voice is pledging to Empower, Prepare and Lead young people to unleash their true potential. By 2021 we aim to be supporting the majority of schools, colleges, universities and youth community groups across the United Kingdom. We pledge to connect with every young person that needs our help. We will level the playing field by supporting our members with the knowledge required to succeed.We will build a truly Limitless Generation.                  What we need We believe that everyone knows someone who would benefit from the Honest Voice platform. For example, your child, niece, nephew, friend or sibling. We are here to offer our support. However we need your help to reach as many young people as possible.Honest Voice needs to raise £25,000 to fund our growth and launch in September 2018. The money that we raise will be spent on building our platform, improving our content and reaching young people across the UK.We will launch building on pre-established relationships with schools, colleges, youth community groups and universities.To grow, to be self-sustaining, and to ensure we build our member base across the UK, Honest Voice will offer its premium content at a low cost monthly or annual subscription. (less than your monthly Netflix membership).                                                                                                                                  Who are we?Honest Voice has been able to build momentum to date through an unwavering level of support from companies, schools, individuals and team members, and we are forever grateful for all of the support.We would like to thank everyone for the continued support they have shown Honest Voice, in particular the Honest Voice team who volunteer their time to make Honest Voice a true success. Team Leads                          Charlene Brown Founder          Joel Westley                                                          Founding Member                                                                                           Himal Patel Founding Member   Dominique Walker                                                              Founding Member                                                                                      Jasmine Shell Founding Member  Sophie RichardsonFounding Member                                  And the wider team... 
Adobea Atsrefi 
Alice Bjorkdahl
Dawn Whyte
Katherine Noble
Laurielle De Boer
Malachi Ferguson 
Reha Begum
Rodney Williams 
Shalina Rahman 
Shaunée James
Sian Johnson-James  
Whitney Joseph 
 FAQ'sWhat will our Platform include?Our platform will be an interactive website and we plan in 2019 to develop an app to amplify accessibility. At Honest Voice our sole focus is to  empower, prepare and support all of our members in all aspects of life, from careers to protecting the mindset. We have therefore split our platform into four key sections that offer a substantive full cycle support system; These sections are Find It, Toolkit, Real Stuff and You. Are we a company or a charity?Honest Voice is a limited company with a social purpose and we chose this option as it allows us to have a much greater impact and be self sustaining. This allows us to continue a high quality level of support without being affected by government funding constraints or cuts.   How will we sustain ourselves as a company?By operating a subscription model we can charge a very affordable membership fee for those who can pay, allowing us to expand our reach and invest in additional content and tools to better support our members. This will also allow us to reach those individuals who don't have the means to access Honest Voice on their own (failing schools, youth offending sites and community interest groups). Collectively we can make a huge difference to generations to come. What is a Company with a Social Purpose?We want to build a limitless generation and fundamentally evolve the careers, life and education support young people and their supporters. We want to change the outcomes for current and future generations. This is our purpose.As mentioned above, Honest Voice is a private limited company and a for profit business. This does not change or diminish our social purpose. Our sole focus is not to sell a product but to offer our members the best opportunity and tools to achieve their dreams and to reach their career and life goals.  Being self sustaining allows us to have unlimited potential for growth.

story:
GIRLS’ VOICES MATTER: Imagination, creativity, confidence!

We want to expand our film course offerings to include a wide array of feminist-inspired instruction. Our courses will address the gaps in so much of the history of film, spotlighting the women whose achievements have not received as much attention as they should have. 

 

OUR TEAM

 

Hi! I’m Erica Goss, Director of Girls’ Voices Matter. I’m a passionate believer in the potential of teen girls. I’m also a teacher and writer, and have worked for many years to help young people express themselves through various forms of storytelling. 

 

I started Girls’ Voices Matter to help empower teenaged girls through storytelling, with a focus on media arts. At Girls’ Voices Matter, girls learn many different forms of artistic expression, from writing poetry to making their own films. 

 

I’m pleased to be working with Dr. Claire Graman. Dr. Graman’s doctorate work focused on feminist film studies, with an emphasis on women in the silent film era and women in comedy. Dr. Graman is an experienced instructor, and will be teaching as well as developing our curriculum.

 

WHY FEMINIST FILM HISTORY IS IMPORTANT

LACK OF REPRESENTATION HURTS GIRLS

As we all know, the lack of women’s representation, especially in film and media, is a critical problem. This can give girls the false assumption that activities such as directing movies are meant only for men, or that a woman must be perfect in order to succeed. This often causes girls to give up early, discouraging them from trying new things, and, eventually, can lead to low self-esteem.

 

DID YOU KNOW…?

WOMEN HAVE ALWAYS BEEN INVOLVED IN MEDIA

Mary Pickford with Camera, ca 1916

So many of women’s achievements in film and media have been ignored or forgotten. 

For example, 

  • Alice Guy-Blaché directed the very first narrative film, The Cabbage Fairy, in 1896.
  • Lotte Reiniger made the first animated film, The Adventures of Prince Achmed, in 1926, eleven years before Disney’s Snow White. She also invented the first multi-plane camera in 1923.
  • Dorothy Arzner invented the boom microphone in 1929.
  • Edith Head won more Academy Awards for costume design than anyone in the history of film.
  • Mary Pickford co-founded the United Artists film studio in 1919.

These are just a few of the many female film pioneers whose names are not as widely known as they should be.

 

WHAT YOU’LL SUPPORT

 

In order to research, develop and launch our Feminist Film Curriculum, we’re asking for $5000. These funds will go towards creating a variety of online courses that will be available in the Spring of 2021.

 

OUR COURSES

 

Women in Independent Film 

Many women directors get started outside the mainstream of Hollywood, in the independent film industry. We’ll explore the challenges and accomplishments of these women, and review their work.

LGBTQ Filmmakers 

The history of LGBTQ filmmakers is one of creativity alongside peril, as accusations of homosexuality could ruin a film career. Many LGBTQ filmmakers maintained a double life while working in the film industry.  We’ll look at their contributions and the conditions they worked under.

History of Women in Animation 

Most people still don’t know that the classics of animated film, such as Snow White and Bambi, were drawn by women whose names never appeared in the credits, or that a women made the first animated film. We’ll uncover their work, as well as the work of women in animation and video games.

Women in Comedy 

Who says women aren’t funny? Slapstick, farce, parody, screwball, dark and romantic comedy—women have always been involved in the various forms of comedy. We’ll survey the accomplishments of these women and review their films.

Feminist Film History: the Silent Era 

Women writers, directors, cinematographers, animators and actors helped create classics of early film, yet most of them have been completely forgotten. We’ll review the reasons for this as well as the work of these film pioneers and their contributions to world of cinema.

Make a Film in a Week for Teen Girls

Scheduled for Spring Break 2021, this class will teach students how to create their own short film. From the first story ideas to the final edits, we’ll go through all of the steps of film creation, including storyboarding, set design, writing scripts, filming, and editing. 

 

OUR GIFTS TO YOU FOR YOUR DONATION

 

Check out our perks! At the $50 level, we’re offering our very own Inspirational Quote sticker package, featuring women filmmakers. For $100, you will receive preferred registration status for any of our online courses. At the $500 level, we’re giving donors a special, behind-the-scenes look into our creative process as we develop our curriculum.

story:
ABOUT US:

ICT FOR ALL IN ALL was founded to drive a much-needed change and turn things around through teaching, consultancy and providing a variety of software development services. Our aim is to facilitate access to ICT education within the local community,  encourage teachers to create a different future for their students by developing their ICT skills and provide a range of tools to give people in communities with a limited or no access to technology a chance to master the basic digital knowledge.



 What we do
1. Education: 
We teach kids to become experts in coding languages including HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Java, and Python. In addition, we guide teachers on how to use interactive tools as part of their tuition and other daily activities.  
2. Consultancy:
Our team helps companies develop the potential and productivity of their workforce by improving their digital literacy. We believe the best way to learn is by doing therefore our onsite training is highly interactive. 
 3. Software and application development:
We design bespoke ICT tools to support efficiency, creativity, and innovation. Our portfolio includes applications that help users with planning, scheduling and search engine optimization.

4. Incubation and Mentoring:  

We provide career guidance to young entrepreneurs and mentor them until the success of their dream project. We are focusing on rural areas for balanced development of all regions of the globe but we do not exclude urban regions.  
Success stories: 


Ever since we started this project our efforts were always met with excitement and enthusiasm to learn. We are glad to have made a difference in our community and continue to work towards achieving our vision.  
Here are some of the milestones we have achieved: 
●     In 2017/2018 we trained 182 kids living in remote areas the basics of programming and text editing using JavaScript, CSS, Python, HTML and MS Word. 
●     We coached 21 professionals in a variety of industries on how to use ICT to become more productive. 
●     Our team developed 47 websites for businesses operating in rural areas to boost the visibility and marketing of their production purposes.
●     We founded Teacher Connect, a global network that brings teachers together to increase their learning potential, enable knowledge sharing and, ultimately, their ability to earn a better income. 

  • In response to COVID-19, we developed the "WE FOR YOU TECHNOLOGIES" platform to enable learners to keep learning from their home. This platform helped much to keep mentoring our beneficiaries remotely and helped the learning institutions to continue their activities during this pandemic crisis.

We want to extend our activities and build a well-equipped incubation center with a computer laboratory that will help us to reach many beneficiaries and serve them with high-quality service.

 

Thank you!

story:
Summary

Empathy. Communication. Collaboration.

 An Igbo word meaning unity, NJIKO is a nonprofit tech startup comprised of volunteers located throughout the world who have come together to use their time, talents, and resources to advance social justice through the use of technology.

 NJIKO seeks to build a platform for continuous discussions of prevalent issues such as racism, xenophobia, tribalism, bullying, domestic violence, sexual abuse amongst others. We want communities to be continuously engaged with these issues through conversations geared toward solving them.

 Our first app, Commix, is the only app dedicated to social justice and nothing else. Commix will be an app that allows people to come together and discuss various social issues. Each user will be able to create or join a group to discuss particular issues. Individuals will also be able to organize a meeting in person and share updates and thoughts within these groups.

 Up to this point, all of the designing and engineering for Commix has come entirely from our own pockets and from our team of volunteers. In order to develop this app, we must cover the costs of development and maintenance as well as various miscellaneous costs associated with app creation and non-profit status. To this end, we have set our goal at $4,500,000, before the end of 2021, which includes all the necessary costs for the initial launch of the app. Currently, the app is set for release in March 2021 on both iOS and Android platforms. As we are all currently unpaid volunteers, your donation is crucial to the success of NJIKO. Please support us and help us actualize our mission: www.njiko.org

 

 

Risks & Challenges

We are worried about privacy concerns we may encounter as we begin on-boarding different groups to use our app.

We are aware that social justice topics like racism, sexual violence, domestic violence, bullying, and many more are sensitive issues that requires us to invest a lot of effort and resources in protecting our user data.

To address this, we plan to hire more information security experts. Currently, we have a Volunteer VP of Information Security who is leading this effort.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We have over 36 volunteers helping us with their skills and talent to create products that will usher a sustainable change in our society. You can volunteer your skills and talent with us: www.njiko.org

story:
Global Health Skills Summer Institute for Youth—The Inspiration 

Following a disastrous accident, a young man came here from Uzbekistan for major facial reconstructive surgery. I read about him in the newspaper, and emailed him, asking whether I could be of help.

The extent of his injuries and the resulting surgeries meant that his education as a medical student back home was over. Since he had that medical background, and since he was so interested in computers, I suggested that he could combine his interests by pursuing a career in medical informatics. We began Visual Basic lessons, and he proved to be a natural at programming.

He applied to, and was accepted by, the highly-competitive computer-science program at the University of Washington. After his acceptance, one of my professors told me that his statement of purpose was so well-written that there was even some speculation among committee members that I had written it for him, since English was his third language. But all doubt that he had written the statement himself was erased in real time one night when this professor and my student began texting each other at 3 AM. From that conversation, it was very clear that his English was, in fact, really that good.

Experiences with students who are that motivated to learn and to succeed are what makes teaching so gratifying and full of joy for me. This project is a proposal to make that volunteer teaching into a full-time job, and a valuable resource for students. 

Summary

I'm asking for donations to provide me with a $10,000 net salary to be able to turn my occasional volunteer tutoring for local refugee and immigrant communities into a funded project that includes a 2-week summer intensive overview of data science, bioinformatics, visualization, and mapping. It's win-win, because in that way, I will have the stable foundation to offer expanded access to technical skills and other educational support to populations who deserve them, yet who don't have a clear path to that support. 

Introduction

My name is Ravensara Travillian. Most people call me Raven, because that's a lot easier to pronounce and to remember. I have been very fortunate in my life, and this project is my way of paying it forward in gratitude to people in my life who helped me when I needed it.

My early background was in mathematics and foreign languages. That focus stood me in good stead when I moved to Seattle in 1987, because the software industry was just getting started in localization: the process for making their software work correctly in foreign languages, as well as being culturally appropriate to the needs and preferences of the intended audiences. I'm very proud of the work I did then in making many different kinds of software available and accessible to non-English-speaking users—not only the languages with major markets such as French and German, but smaller (in market attention, if not in numbers), less-well-served languages such as Arabic, Hebrew, simplified Chinese, and Finnish as well.

That experience is where I first committed myself to making the power of valid information equally accessible for everyone. Everything I've worked at since then--working at the Refugee Clinic at Harborview Medical Center, returning to the University of Washington to complete a PhD in Biomedical & Health Informatics, making hot food for my local food bank, helping to develop a clinic's community healthy-food garden, and now, working as a data scientist in global health--has been in the service of that commitment.

The market niche in the communities

This campaign is important to me because I'm committed to increasing access to the empowerment that information provides for everyone. And I know it's important to the intended audience, because of what happened when I attended a party at the home of a couple of leaders in one of the Seattle-area refugee communities.

I was chatting with one of the hosts, and I made an off-hand remark about how I thought I'd like to teach a programming class for young adults from the community someday. The conversation moved on to other topics, and I didn't give my casual remark any further thought until when--in less than half an hour--a small group approached me shyly, with a list of their email addresses, and asked me if I would be their teacher.

That is how deep the respect for learning and the hunger for programming knowledge runs in the community--word of our conversation had gotten around at the party, and the group--who, of course, I formed a study group with right away--wanted to pin down the details to make it happen right away. This group studied together for almost 3 years before the responsibilities of their lives (becoming parents; coping with life changes; becoming the first one in their family to ever attend and graduate from college) took them in different directions. But their eagerness and passion for learning, and their initiative in reaching out--based on nothing more than a casual conversation at a party--made a deep impression on me as a teacher.

What I'm asking for

I am a "born teacher", as one of my committee members observed at my dissertation defense; I am a committed and industrious volunteer for making information and resources more equitably available, and I have a wide variety of education and experience in academia and in the tech industry in Seattle. I would love to use all of these aspects of my experience to team up with you to create a joint project for the benefit of refugee and other underserved communities in the Seattle area, and I am asking for your help to make this happen.

 

 

These classes will not be enough, in themselves, to turn them into data scientists or bioinformaticists, but they will help the students to see what's possible for them in their careers, what steps they can take in order to get there, and what resources exist to support them along the way. I don't expect to be able to cram all the necessary material into our short time together. Rather, I want to spark a flame and passion for learning, and an awareness that yes--given time and effort--they, too, are capable of work and education that they may have assumed is out of their reach.

 

The need

I seek $10,000 salary (net) to be able to make the transition from volunteer teaching to teaching as my entrepreneurial venture.

The value that I will provide in return for the $10,000 is to organize, develop, and teach a pilot project consisting of a 2-week set of modular classes focused on capacity-building in computer technology and data science for global health, and tailored for youth from local communities that do not have access to the same educational resources that many Americans are able to take for granted.  This project is the Global Health Skills Summer Institute for Youth. If the first year is successful, then I will commit to carrying it out every summer through 2025, as well as to training younger people to carry it on (capacity-building) once I pass the torch to them.

 

 

The impact of your support

Your donations will enable me to resume my scientific and teaching career from where I had to leave it because of a medical ordeal. I am grateful for the opportunity to simultaneously:

  1. improve my housing security far beyond what I am capable of on my own;
  2. get my scientific research and teaching career back on track; and
  3. commit to empowering a group of deserving, passionate, and responsible young people to making the world better.

If you've read this far, then I think that we share the goal of making the world better for our presence in it. This project makes progress on that front by addressing several hard challenges:

  • The prospective students are balancing the equivalent of multiple full-time jobs, on multiple fronts. One major responsibility they have assumed is taking care of their parents and others in their communities who haven't adapted to the United States as thoroughly as the prospective students have. In addition to that work, many of them are now parents themselves, so they are raising their children. They hold down jobs, and some of them are now going to college to continue their education.

The way that they are shouldering these responsibilities demonstrates their work ethic, as well as their skill and resilience in working out solutions to problems that arise. Additionally, they have a commitment and relationship to the areas of their family's origin through their parents and communities. They are motivated and hard-working, and will be great college students and employees, if given educational opportunities.

  • The terrain: as a professional in scientific publishing, I have witnessed the activity behind the scenes that both research universities and publishers are taking to expand their pools of researchers and reviewers to include demographically or geographically under-represented voices. They are serious in their efforts to increase diversity in the data science world, and by providing another path to those skills, the Summer Institute can help both the students who are looking for careers, and the institutions who seek to grow their outreach to more diverse candidates.

 

What you will get in return

Because I appreciate this opportunity so much, I want to show my appreciation by providing unique perks to donors who make it possible. There are different levels of support, with different perks that you receive, and you can read about them in more detail in the Perks section. They range from Summer Institute-themed keepsakes, to personal progress reports, to participation in a recognition dinner.

I am using the Indiegogo flexible funding option. That means that, if I don't reach my entire goal in the month that this campaign lasts, I get to keep the funds that I was able to raise. But since that doesn't accomplish the goal of saving 3 months' rent to give to my landlords in advance, I am pursuing other paths as well to earn or save supplementary funds. I will combine them with the funds I raise through this campaign, and in this way, accomplish my goal of housing security.

If I reach more than my entire goal, I will use the surplus funds to reach out to more communities to repeat this series more often, including capacity-building efforts to empower more peer support and paths to success for more youth.

Risks & Challenges

I don't want to pretend that this will be easy--what I am proposing is a great deal of hard work, and there are risks and challenges ahead of us. I am taking those into account as I develop my plan. And I have qualities to help me face those challenges, and a track record of not giving up.

I persevere. I am passionate about protecting everyone, and taking care of one another. If I am blocked by challenges, I will find another way around them.

I am overpreparing, in order to make sure that I have redundancies that I can rely on if one avenue fails. 

I have a track record of success in initiating and completing projects, described in more detail in the FAQ. I am confident that, with your support, I can develop and deliver in abundance on the proposed Summer Institute project. Together, we can make a real and positive impact in multiple ways

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not in a position to contribute money right now, please know that I understand! I've been at similar points in my life, as well--and not that long ago, either. I remember what it felt like, and I want you to know that I'm grateful for your moral support and encouragement. It means so much more than I can say. Just knowing that people I respect value this project reinforces that it's the right career path for me.

If you're looking for other specific ways to help, Indiegogo has share tools for social media that you could use to boost the signal about this campaign.

You could also write a letter of support, explaining the value you see in this project, and inviting others to support it as well.

If you're interested, we can talk more about it. But please understand that knowing I have your emotional support is already very valuable, and I hope you can see how much it means to me in helping make this project possible.

 

Finally, I want to express my deep gratitude to my students who have given me permission to share these pictures from our experience together. I have learned a lot from all of my students, and I am in awe, both of what you have the potential for, and of what you are already doing.
story_txt:
Global Health Skills Summer Institute for Youth—The Inspiration 
Following a disastrous accident, a young man came here from Uzbekistan for major facial reconstructive surgery. I read about him in the newspaper, and emailed him, asking whether I could be of help.The extent of his injuries and the resulting surgeries meant that his education as a medical student back home was over. Since he had that medical background, and since he was so interested in computers, I suggested that he could combine his interests by pursuing a career in medical informatics. We began Visual Basic lessons, and he proved to be a natural at programming.He applied to, and was accepted by, the highly-competitive computer-science program at the University of Washington. After his acceptance, one of my professors told me that his statement of purpose was so well-written that there was even some speculation among committee members that I had written it for him, since English was his third language. But all doubt that he had written the statement himself was erased in real time one night when this professor and my student began texting each other at 3 AM. From that conversation, it was very clear that his English was, in fact, really that good.Experiences with students who are that motivated to learn and to succeed are what makes teaching so gratifying and full of joy for me. This project is a proposal to make that volunteer teaching into a full-time job, and a valuable resource for students. SummaryI'm asking for donations to provide me with a $10,000 net salary to be able to turn my occasional volunteer tutoring for local refugee and immigrant communities into a funded project that includes a 2-week summer intensive overview of data science, bioinformatics, visualization, and mapping. It's win-win, because in that way, I will have the stable foundation to offer expanded access to technical skills and other educational support to populations who deserve them, yet who don't have a clear path to that support. IntroductionMy name is Ravensara Travillian. Most people call me Raven, because that's a lot easier to pronounce and to remember. I have been very fortunate in my life, and this project is my way of paying it forward in gratitude to people in my life who helped me when I needed it.My early background was in mathematics and foreign languages. That focus stood me in good stead when I moved to Seattle in 1987, because the software industry was just getting started in localization: the process for making their software work correctly in foreign languages, as well as being culturally appropriate to the needs and preferences of the intended audiences. I'm very proud of the work I did then in making many different kinds of software available and accessible to non-English-speaking users—not only the languages with major markets such as French and German, but smaller (in market attention, if not in numbers), less-well-served languages such as Arabic, Hebrew, simplified Chinese, and Finnish as well.That experience is where I first committed myself to making the power of valid information equally accessible for everyone. Everything I've worked at since then--working at the Refugee Clinic at Harborview Medical Center, returning to the University of Washington to complete a PhD in Biomedical & Health Informatics, making hot food for my local food bank, helping to develop a clinic's community healthy-food garden, and now, working as a data scientist in global health--has been in the service of that commitment.The market niche in the communitiesThis campaign is important to me because I'm committed to increasing access to the empowerment that information provides for everyone. And I know it's important to the intended audience, because of what happened when I attended a party at the home of a couple of leaders in one of the Seattle-area refugee communities.I was chatting with one of the hosts, and I made an off-hand remark about how I thought I'd like to teach a programming class for young adults from the community someday. The conversation moved on to other topics, and I didn't give my casual remark any further thought until when--in less than half an hour--a small group approached me shyly, with a list of their email addresses, and asked me if I would be their teacher.That is how deep the respect for learning and the hunger for programming knowledge runs in the community--word of our conversation had gotten around at the party, and the group--who, of course, I formed a study group with right away--wanted to pin down the details to make it happen right away. This group studied together for almost 3 years before the responsibilities of their lives (becoming parents; coping with life changes; becoming the first one in their family to ever attend and graduate from college) took them in different directions. But their eagerness and passion for learning, and their initiative in reaching out--based on nothing more than a casual conversation at a party--made a deep impression on me as a teacher.What I'm asking forI am a "born teacher", as one of my committee members observed at my dissertation defense; I am a committed and industrious volunteer for making information and resources more equitably available, and I have a wide variety of education and experience in academia and in the tech industry in Seattle. I would love to use all of these aspects of my experience to team up with you to create a joint project for the benefit of refugee and other underserved communities in the Seattle area, and I am asking for your help to make this happen.  These classes will not be enough, in themselves, to turn them into data scientists or bioinformaticists, but they will help the students to see what's possible for them in their careers, what steps they can take in order to get there, and what resources exist to support them along the way. I don't expect to be able to cram all the necessary material into our short time together. Rather, I want to spark a flame and passion for learning, and an awareness that yes--given time and effort--they, too, are capable of work and education that they may have assumed is out of their reach. The needI seek $10,000 salary (net) to be able to make the transition from volunteer teaching to teaching as my entrepreneurial venture.The value that I will provide in return for the $10,000 is to organize, develop, and teach a pilot project consisting of a 2-week set of modular classes focused on capacity-building in computer technology and data science for global health, and tailored for youth from local communities that do not have access to the same educational resources that many Americans are able to take for granted.  This project is the Global Health Skills Summer Institute for Youth. If the first year is successful, then I will commit to carrying it out every summer through 2025, as well as to training younger people to carry it on (capacity-building) once I pass the torch to them.  The impact of your supportYour donations will enable me to resume my scientific and teaching career from where I had to leave it because of a medical ordeal. I am grateful for the opportunity to simultaneously:
improve my housing security far beyond what I am capable of on my own;
get my scientific research and teaching career back on track; and
commit to empowering a group of deserving, passionate, and responsible young people to making the world better.
If you've read this far, then I think that we share the goal of making the world better for our presence in it. This project makes progress on that front by addressing several hard challenges:The prospective students are balancing the equivalent of multiple full-time jobs, on multiple fronts. One major responsibility they have assumed is taking care of their parents and others in their communities who haven't adapted to the United States as thoroughly as the prospective students have. In addition to that work, many of them are now parents themselves, so they are raising their children. They hold down jobs, and some of them are now going to college to continue their education.The way that they are shouldering these responsibilities demonstrates their work ethic, as well as their skill and resilience in working out solutions to problems that arise. Additionally, they have a commitment and relationship to the areas of their family's origin through their parents and communities. They are motivated and hard-working, and will be great college students and employees, if given educational opportunities.The terrain: as a professional in scientific publishing, I have witnessed the activity behind the scenes that both research universities and publishers are taking to expand their pools of researchers and reviewers to include demographically or geographically under-represented voices. They are serious in their efforts to increase diversity in the data science world, and by providing another path to those skills, the Summer Institute can help both the students who are looking for careers, and the institutions who seek to grow their outreach to more diverse candidates. What you will get in returnBecause I appreciate this opportunity so much, I want to show my appreciation by providing unique perks to donors who make it possible. There are different levels of support, with different perks that you receive, and you can read about them in more detail in the Perks section. They range from Summer Institute-themed keepsakes, to personal progress reports, to participation in a recognition dinner.I am using the Indiegogo flexible funding option. That means that, if I don't reach my entire goal in the month that this campaign lasts, I get to keep the funds that I was able to raise. But since that doesn't accomplish the goal of saving 3 months' rent to give to my landlords in advance, I am pursuing other paths as well to earn or save supplementary funds. I will combine them with the funds I raise through this campaign, and in this way, accomplish my goal of housing security.If I reach more than my entire goal, I will use the surplus funds to reach out to more communities to repeat this series more often, including capacity-building efforts to empower more peer support and paths to success for more youth.Risks & ChallengesI don't want to pretend that this will be easy--what I am proposing is a great deal of hard work, and there are risks and challenges ahead of us. I am taking those into account as I develop my plan. And I have qualities to help me face those challenges, and a track record of not giving up.I persevere. I am passionate about protecting everyone, and taking care of one another. If I am blocked by challenges, I will find another way around them.I am overpreparing, in order to make sure that I have redundancies that I can rely on if one avenue fails. I have a track record of success in initiating and completing projects, described in more detail in the FAQ. I've been at similar points in my life, as well--and not that long ago, either. I remember what it felt like, and I want you to know that I'm grateful for your moral support and encouragement. It means so much more than I can say. Just knowing that people I respect value this project reinforces that it's the right career path for me.If you're looking for other specific ways to help, Indiegogo has share tools for social media that you could use to boost the signal about this campaign.You could also write a letter of support, explaining the value you see in this project, and inviting others to support it as well.If you're interested, we can talk more about it. But please understand that knowing I have your emotional support is already very valuable, and I hope you can see how much it means to me in helping make this project possible. Finally, I want to express my deep gratitude to my students who have given me permission to share these pictures from our experience together. I have learned a lot from all of my students, and I am in awe, both of what you have the potential for, and of what you are already doing.

story:
Her name is Da. She is 16 years old. She should be spiking volleyballs on the varsity team, studying Geometry or reciting lines for the school play.

 

But Da won’t have that opportunity. She lives in Chiang Mai, Thailand and instead of heading to class...she  has been forced into the dark world of abuse and sexual slavery….forced to succumb to the perversions of men who see her as nothing but a servant to their perverse needs.

 

Meanwhile, in Ethiopia, Yonus can’t attend school. He has to help his family survive by bearing the load of a 5 gallon jug on his back just so he can collect dirty water for his family to cook with...and drink. The chore takes half a day.

 

Da and Yonus are real kids. In fact, there are 264,000,000 students who did not go to school last year and who will not attend this year either… at least not without our help. Some of them are bound to the child labor system, others are victims of sex trafficking and many more are stuck in poverty, where half of their day is consumed just to find water.

 

Why You Should Care

 

Can you imagine the potential that could lay in students like Da and Yonus? Perhaps the solutions to cure cancer, reduce world hunger or find more economical energy sources are locked in their brains. The key to unlocking this potential? Education.

By flipping the traditional model of education upside down and providing the opportunity to attend online, we are able to reduce costs for international students by 80%.

 

And from the 20% they do pay? A part of every dollar earned is set aside for needy students around the world… just like Da and Yonus.

 

How Is This Possible?

American College Preparatory Academy (ACPA) was created to meet the needs of an underserved market segment; students who desire to attend an excellent United States high school to prepare for an American college experience.... but can’t afford both.

By leveraging the newest innovations in communication and technology, and tapping into the Founder’s decades of experience in placing graduates at elite colleges and universities throughout the United States, ACPA is designed to offer a superior U.S. high school education at a fraction of the price of a traditional US boarding school.

Instead of international students paying $50,000 per year to study in the U.S. for 10 months and then go home for 2, ACPA students will study in their home country for 10 months and travel to the U.S. for 2 months… all for less than $10,000.  During those two months they will enhance their English language skills, practice for the SAT and ACT and visit colleges and major cities throughout the nation.

We have partnered with one of the best curriculum providers in the US to connect excellent teachers and world-class course work to students to give our students the chance to realize their dream of attending college in America.

 

 

Why Now?

 

There are 4 elements necessary for an international student to succeed in a U.S. college or university:

- Rigorous fully accredited high school coursework,

- English language skills,

- U.S. cultural awareness,

- and individualized college guidance and placement.

 

All of these elements must be anchored by the connection with a caring, relational teacher/mentor.  

Advancements in the tech sector have finally made the missing link of allowing for strong student-teacher relationships, even in an online education.

 

 

With technology like Facetime, Zoom, Tango, Google hangout, ooVoo and Skype, students can have real-time, face to face connection with their teachers - teachers who connect, encourage, inspire and challenge their students everyday.

 

Making It Happen

 

The goal is to enroll the first class of ACPA in August of 2019.

To do so, we need to reach the funding goal of $12,000 in order to build an online education that truly is designed to serve everyone...even those in the most dire of circumstances.  

We believe that the greatest untapped resource in the world is the human mind, but 80% of the kids in the world will never realize their full potential without an education.

We have the ability to change that. A portion of every dollar received will go into a scholarship fund for needy students. As they step are provided the opportunity to step into their potential and passions… we all benefit as they help change the world.

 

 

About The Founder

 

Richard Miller has spent 40 years as a teacher and administrator helping American students develop their gifts, hidden potential and find their life callings.

 

For the past 10 years, Mr. Miller has been working with a brick and mortar International Student Boarding program at the school where he has served for 20 years. Through this experience, he has visited schools in Africa, Thailand and China. His contacts in those countries are aiding to boost awareness the cause. This is how he met Da and Yonus.

 

 

While visiting a town in Ethiopia where students had to win a literal lottery to attend “school”(a mudbrick building with no windows), he felt the call to make education accessible. This was solidified when he realized students who didn’t win a seat were walking for miles a day just to sit outside the school in hopes of hearing any scrap of knowledge through the walls.

 

While visiting Da, he asked those who knew her if she would be allowed to study if a computer was provided. They said yes.  

 

As a father and grandfather, he wishes that all children could have the same educational opportunities as his own.He is now committing to put his decades of experience to work on behalf of students all around the world.  

 

His dream was to develop a school to make education more affordable for international students who can pay, while also using a portion of the profits to fund scholarships to provide education to those kids around the world who are just waiting outside the walls...and ACPA is the dream.

 

 

Risks & Challenges

 

At this point the biggest risk and challenge is enrolling enough students for a soft rollout, beginning with the new school year in September of 2019.

In order to establish “proof of concept,”  we will need to enroll between 10 and 20 students. This Indiegogo campaign was designed to fund a social media marketing blitz for the next 120 days.

We know who our target audience is, we have curriculum and websites in place and teachers ready to go. Additionally, we have partnered with one of the most reliable online providers in the U.S.

We are starting with the English speaking countries outside of the U.S. for the first 60 days and then will add additional countries as we progress.  Your financial support over the next 90 days allows us to open ACPA and enroll our first class of students in August of 2019. Your dollars will help make a top quality education a reality for kids who may have previously been locked out by poverty or circumstance.

story:
Our association, based in Croatia, was founded with the mission of promoting the importance of film music and its composers, as well as film sound through organization of the International Sound and Film Music Festival. By holding the festival year after year we want to encourage creative and constructive discussions about the indelible link between film and music, to connect people, advice, educate young composers as well as other film music enthusiasts through discussion panels, seminars, film market and networking.

This year we would like to fund 10 students from all around the world to join us in Pula, Croatia from 20th-22nd of October and offer them the possibility to learn and meet professionals from the film music industry.

Collected funds will be used to cover the expenses of accreditation for the festival and 2-night hotel accommodation (B&B).

With your support you can help young people to become active members of this creative community and bring them to the doorstep of their future musical career.

You can find all about us and our work at http://www.isfmf.com or feel the atmosphere of the last year's edition at https://vimeo.com/193409831

story:
About Me

I am an IT professional with over six years working in education and the rehabilitation of militants and internally displaced persons. In recent years I’ve developed an interest in Project Management and Business Analysis and slowly pivoted towards this field. I have a bachelor’s degree in Mathematics/Computer Science from the Federal University of Technology, Minna, Nigeria and a master’s degree in Management of Information Technology from the University of Nottingham, United Kingdom. I was motivated to make this pivot in my last role as the IT Projects Officer at Combat & General Strategy International (CGSI), an organisation dedicated to the rehabilitation and re-integration of internally displaced persons, I always wanted to be able to offer more.

My experience with CGSI and the difficulties that Nigerian youth like myself continue to face with securing employment motivated me to determine how skill acquisition could be deployed for youth development and alleviate the increasing unemployment rates in Nigeria. Because of my background, my goal is to make technology an integral part of the skills acquisition process.

To execute the next phase of this goal, I applied for the IDEX Global Fellowship Program for social intrapreneurs. I was accepted into the programme and offered a grant scholarship of $1000.

 

Funding My Journey to Becoming  A Social Intrapreneur

The IDEX Fellowship Program is a six-month programme commencing on the 2nd of July 2018 and ending on the 21st of December 2018. It is a tuition based program with a fee of $2,950 and amounts to $9262.5 when other pertinent costs are included. Consequently, I’m reaching out to friends, family and people who wish to support me in my journey toward productive social entrepreneurship to raise the funds to cover:

  • Tuition Fees
  • Return Flight Ticket
  • Medical/Travel Insurance
  • Business Visa
  • Accommodation & Utilities
  • Transportation in India

To view a more detailed cost breakdown, I have included a link to an excel sheet detailing the expenses: https://1drv.ms/x/s!Alu2orzHLJTslVppK4y_CxyyeJZl

 

The IDEX Global Fellowship Program

IDEX stands for Intrapreneur Development Experience. Their mission is to create the next wave of “social intrapreneurs” who will support, lead and advance the work of socially-focused enterprises around the world. Social intrapreneurs are becoming key actors in the race towards a new kind of economy. These change-makers are supporting and leading the development of scalable solutions to some of the world’s most pressing challenges - from health to education to environment. Contrary to social entrepreneurs, social intrapreneurs are innovating from within an existing enterprise or organization.

The Global Fellow Program offers 6 months of intense emerging market field experience and leadership training that equips fellows with 2 years of marketable experience. To learn more about the IDEX Global Fellowship Program, visit: http://www.idexfellows.com/

 

Ways You Can Help

There are multiple ways you can help me achieve my dreams of going to India! I’m aware that not everyone will be able to offer help financially, but these are things you can do:

  • Share my Indiegogo link! Spread the word! Thanks to the internet and social media, it’s a lot easier to share information quickly and across vast distances.
  • Networking is key. I’m currently searching for acquaintances in Bangalore that can share experiences and information which could help me hit the ground running when I eventually arrive.

In recent years I’ve developed an interest in Project Management and Business Analysis and slowly pivoted towards this field. I have a bachelor’s degree in Mathematics/Computer Science from the Federal University of Technology, Minna, Nigeria and a master’s degree in Management of Information Technology from the University of Nottingham, United Kingdom. I was motivated to make this pivot in my last role as the IT Projects Officer at Combat & General Strategy International (CGSI), an organisation dedicated to the rehabilitation and re-integration of internally displaced persons, I always wanted to be able to offer more.
My experience with CGSI and the difficulties that Nigerian youth like myself continue to face with securing employment motivated me to determine how skill acquisition could be deployed for youth development and alleviate the increasing unemployment rates in Nigeria. Because of my background, my goal is to make technology an integral part of the skills acquisition process.To execute the next phase of this goal, I applied for the IDEX Global Fellowship Program for social intrapreneurs. I was accepted into the programme and offered a grant scholarship of $1000. 
Funding My Journey to Becoming  A Social Intrapreneur
The IDEX Fellowship Program is a six-month programme commencing on the 2nd of July 2018 and ending on the 21st of December 2018. It is a tuition based program with a fee of $2,950 and amounts to $9262.5 when other pertinent costs are included. Consequently, I’m reaching out to friends, family and people who wish to support me in my journey toward productive social entrepreneurship to raise the funds to cover:
Tuition Fees
Return Flight Ticket
Medical/Travel Insurance
Business Visa
Accommodation & Utilities
Transportation in India
To view a more detailed cost breakdown, I have included a link to an excel sheet detailing the expenses: https://1drv.ms/x/s!Alu2orzHLJTslVppK4y_CxyyeJZl 
The IDEX Global Fellowship Program
IDEX stands for Intrapreneur Development Experience. Their mission is to create the next wave of “social intrapreneurs” who will support, lead and advance the work of socially-focused enterprises around the world. Social intrapreneurs are becoming key actors in the race towards a new kind of economy. These change-makers are supporting and leading the development of scalable solutions to some of the world’s most pressing challenges - from health to education to environment. Contrary to social entrepreneurs, social intrapreneurs are innovating from within an existing enterprise or organization.
The Global Fellow Program offers 6 months of intense emerging market field experience and leadership training that equips fellows with 2 years of marketable experience. To learn more about the IDEX Global Fellowship Program, visit: http://www.idexfellows.com/
 

Ways You Can Help
There are multiple ways you can help me achieve my dreams of going to India! I’m aware that not everyone will be able to offer help financially, but these are things you can do:

Share my Indiegogo link! Spread the word! Thanks to the internet and social media, it’s a lot easier to share information quickly and across vast distances.
Networking is key. I’m currently searching for acquaintances in Bangalore that can share experiences and information which could help me hit the ground running when I eventually arrive.

story:
Fight like your grandad 

This book is my take on aggregating the works of British WW2 Combatives and Self Defence Instructors, primarily the methods of the legend that is W.E Fairbairn.

It includes over 200 image laden pages of original content that showcases the development of the material from the early Shanghai Municipal Police years through to World War 2. 

The book will have clear lucid photography and be very much designed as a training manual by, and for, martial artists. 

I am a boxer, judoka and all-round martial artist, founder of the Bartitsu Lab and I hope that my writing style and step by step process make the book a great find for the experienced self defence practitioner and newbie alike. 

 

What's in the book?

It contains clear and comprehensive how-to guides on:

  • Striking 
  • Grappling (throws, locks, chokes)
  • How to use and defend against Baton, FS Knife, Smatchet, pistol and rifle 
  • Defences against HAPV (habituals acts of physical violence) 
  • Awareness, fight psychology and strategy 

 

The material makes it very easy to follow and provides extra depth and detail for readers familiar with the works which could not be included in the concise editions. This includes how to chain together combinations, how and where to best apply them, and tips for training them at home or in your dojo.  

The material also takes a look at supporting and ancillary work including:

  • British Military Boxing / Boxing of the 1940s 
  • The weapons of the SOE 
  • Additional content from 1920s - 1940s Judo, Ju Jitsu and other arts that make up WW2 Combatives 

 

This will be my second book, following the Bartitsu book I published in September 2020. 

 

What you get

The book has already been written, and photographed. It is being laid out as we speak, ready for final proofing, sense check and finalisation. It was shot in WW2 clothing, at a historic aerodrome and is a great read for anyone interested in:

  • WW2
  • Early Krav Maga / Kapap 
  • Self Defence / Combatives 
  • Martial arts 

 

It'll be in A5 Landscape format and be easy to follow, easy to apply and a great addition to any serious martial artists' book collection. 

The £30 covers delivery to anywhere in the UK or Europe. For US or outside of that zone it's £38 (don't blame, blame postage costs!). £50  gets you a "Fight like your grandad" T shirt too! 

 

 

If you have any questions or queries please do ask, I am more than happy to answer. Print date, early October 2020.

Stay safe and train well, 

 

Tommy Joe Moore

story:
What's a Reading Pacer?

Reading Pacers are a carefully designed system of nine reading guides and a reading coach's manual. Reading Pacers boost reading efficiency by training readers to decrease distractions, regressions, develop reading rhythms, and create effective eye movements.

Most of us are still using the same reading skills we were taught in grade school. Reading Pacers break the old reading mindset. This method is for goal-driven individuals who need more control over their time and who have a passion for knowledge.

The Impact

Our product has been tested in the classroom. Our product will help reduce the drop out rate, inspire confidence, and change reading mindset. You can coach others to use it. This reading method is designed for at least a 6th grade reading ability.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for $45,000 to cover our final production costs and advertising. The product molds have already been made and 5000 units have been produced. The reading manual is done and needs to be printed. Some packaging materials have already been purchased. Product can be shipped in plus/minus 30 days and will be sold through Amazon.

A $20.00 donation gets the Reading Pacer set, which includes 9 reading guides, 3 handles (means 3 people can use it), 15 pages of nuts and bolts reading instructions, and free shipping cost in the US. What only 20 bucks? Your contribution is sincerely appreciated for production/labor.

Challenges

We have skin in game and no debt at this point! Our biggest challenge will be advertising the product and getting the word out. We are developing a well-conceived program which includes, social media, display advertising, email campaigns, use of Google ad-words, and proven affiliates programs.

story:
Short Summary

Our goal is to teach children of the world to READ English no matter what native language they SPEAK. Our plan is to launch a cloud-based service that provides a digitalized, proven English reading curriculum with audio instruction and prompts in the native language of the student. The ABLEStudent program has students learn at their own pace with a continuous experience of success.  We will initially offer the audio instructions in Spanish (and English) but plan to provide audio instruction in other key languages spoken in North America (Chinese, Vietnamese, Korean, Tagalog, Russian, Arabic, Somali, Inuit, Navajo, etc) over time. The successful funding of this initial project will enable us to focus on Spanish, and English speakers for grades K through 3. 

Mike Aberth is the co-founder of ABLEStudent and  has 30 year experience as an elementary, middle and high school teacher in an inner city school system in Ohio, He saw the potential for adapting this unique curriculum for ESL and English speaking students to access on the web.

 During his teaching career he saw many different methods and reading curriculums come and go. Over the years many different waves of children from immigrant families have entered the school system. He came across and extensively used this proven reading curriculum (in a hard copy format) that was used by over 4,000,000 students in North America.  ABLEStudent has negotiated the exclusive rights to use this reading curriculum for electronic distribution.

We see this program being used in the home, in schools, and after school programs.  Homeschoolers could use ABLEStudent as a primary tool for instruction and schools and other programs could use as a supplemental tool in the classroom. The ABLEStudent program allows teachers to successfully teach classes of multiple native speakers, all using the same reading program. Our program will work on any device (PC, Tablet, Smartphone) that utilizes a modern browser and has access to the internet. It does not require any software to be downloaded.

 

What We Need & What You Get

To this point we have spent approximately $90,000 of our own money on this project  creating a digital architecture, working demo, and prototype but we need to raise another $90,000  to accomplish 4 major tasks and allow us to complete and bring  the program to the public.

  • Digitize the remainder of the curriculum 
  • Record the teaching instructions in Spanish and English
  • Program and input all materials
  • Upgrade the software to handle a large number of users and make the program available to individuals, schools, and nonprofits 

The Impact

According to the US Census Bureau there are 10.5 million families in the US where English is not spoken as the primary language at home. The children from these homes are at distinct disadvantage when they go to school as the primary language of instruction is often English. Some schools have bilingual teachers and aides, but many do not.  Children who do not develop reading skills during early primary education are on a lifetime trajectory of limited educational progress and, therefore, limited economic opportunities.  Not being able to read limits a person’s opportunities in society. Although an individual's future is not solely dependent on their ability to read, reading is a critical precondition for skills development. The ABLEStudent program will make reading English available to children and adults no matter their language of origin with an experience of continuous success. Your contribution will make a difference in the lives of every user.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our project with all your friends and associates on social media and encourage their support. Check out the Indiegogo share tools and help us "Teach the World to Read - English".

.

story:
Hello my name is Troy, and i love Hockey.

  due medical problems i cant play in game anymore.  but i strive to help the youth learn.  

With this i would love to raise enough money to give as many kids as possible free hockey gear and lessons.  i would like to provide low income familys the opertunity to get there child into hockey.  I belive sports are crucial to a child upbringing, keeping them out of trouble and focused on something more positive.

I would personally be offering the lessons, i would be using some of the money to rent out some ice time on a regular basis in order to invite these children to come learn how to skate, stick handle, block, shoot, deke, goaltend, everything.  

I am willing to help each child learn in there trouble areas.  there will be alot of games involved in teaching them, helping them learn to love the sport rather then just focus on winning.

this is for a 1 year program.  i would need to take care of my family as if i was working a regular full time job so in turn i would take a minimal salary of my own out of the money  %20. which when considering the cost of living near vancouver bc is a very low salary to pay myself. 

no matter how much or how little i raise i will still be putting this money into the community to help kids that cant afford to get into sports.  that cant afford the equipment.   

any and all purchase records and salary pay will always be avaiable to any doner at there request.

story:
My name is Bridger Frederick, I am a 23 year old kid with a dream of travelling around the world by bicycle, while building up a network of people who eventually want to come together in the future and build a community with a certain set of principles and ideals aimed at personal growth while minimizing our cost to the planet. A community with a different mind-set and way of life that actually promotes health and happiness. My launch pad for this whole idea will be my writing and other projects while I am cycling and camping my way up the length of Africa and beyond, living off the average daily wage of the people in each country. There will be a cap of ten dollars a day and a minimum $1.14 per day in Burundi.

This trip is about so much more than just the immense personal growth that will naturally stem from such a diverse and arduous journey through so many different environments and countries. It's about spreading education and inspiring people to realize their dreams despite any obstacles in their way. The magnitude and impact of this project is infinite. I am thinking 40 years into the future and the skills, knowledge, network, capital and assets I am going to need to flourish in that world and this is the first step in a massive start up. And to be frank I need your help. I have depleted my bank accounts on the flights, gear, most of the bikes paid off, immunizations and a myriad of other expenses. The $5000 goal is for the ongoing funding of the trip. Money will be spent on food, writing materials, internet access, bike maintenance, and self publishing of some books I'm composing. Contributors can also rest assured that they will see exactly how the money is being used as I am creating a financial breakdown of the entire trip, to show fellow adventure enthusiasts exactly what it takes to see the world.

I must emphasise that no matter what comes of this crowdfunding venture I'll be in Africa within the next 48 hours, pedalling away and that's where you'll find me for the next couple years regardless of outside funding. This funding will be a massive jumpstart to sharing this adventure this with the world.

The not so tangible reason for becoming a part of this project and fueling it with capitol is that I can from the depths of my heart say you will play a part in my goal of leaving some sort of long lasting positive impact on this earth. My gratitude would be infinite as you would be directly contributing to my dreams with your hard earned cash and that to me is an inspiration in itself. I want to share my story with the world, because the turbulent events of my life to date have lead me to a firm belief that happiness and success are founded exclusively on establishing and living by a certain set of rock hard, unwavering principles that guide your life. And because of the happiness and empowerment adopting this has brought me I feel as though bringing that into the lives of the ones I love and all people is simply the next step.

I am going to Africa to ride from the bottom of the continent to the top. The risks and challenges I face will be many and immense I am sure. The shear physical intensity of riding a bike with everything I own through the deserts, mountains, forests, and jungles of Africa will be arduous as it gets. Combining that with the mental intensity of a being surround by extremely different cultures and often extreme poverty adds the next tier of risk and challenge. But that's exploration, that's adventure and that's what I thrive off. It's when I'm my happiest, my most creative and my most perceptive. It spurs, ignites and drives the infinite energy I feel inside me towards something greater than myself.

This is my dream and any contribution would be you helping me realize it. Monetary contributions are a massive help and so essential to the trip but if that isn't an option for you sharing this with people who would find this story interesting or want to be a part of this project is an equal or greater contribution on its own in making this project move forward. Thank you so much for even taking the time to read about my life and welcome to the adventure.
